fields.description: You manage to remain unseen throughout the day as the huntress goes about her work. She kills several rabbits and an impressive buck deer, but does not meet a single soul.
fields.title: Far Traveler

fields.description: The boy realizes that you've been following him, and loses you by running through a crowded marketplace. You vow to use more caution next time.
fields.title: Spotted!

fields.description:
How unusual! The boy usually only pauses for a few moments in front of each door, either delivering or taking a letter, but at one house he enters and remains inside for some time. Sneaking closer to the window, you spy him sitting with several men and women. Their clothes look foreign... are they from House Gol, perhaps? Or maybe the Republic?

The evidence seems circumstantial, but still worth reporting to Temor. He is happy to pay you for your observation, and asks you to continue gathering information.
fields.title: A Suspicious Meeting

fields.description:
How unusual! The boy usually only pauses for a few moments in front of each door, either delivering or taking a letter, but at one house he enters and remains inside for some time. Sneaking closer to the window, you spy him sitting with several men and women. Their clothes look foreign... are they from House Gol, perhaps? Or maybe the Republic?

Emboldened, you creep even nearer the house until you can hear their conversation. It sounds like the strangers are distant relatives who plan to form a letter-delivery service that will run throughout Skal. An ambitious plan, certainly, but likely not connected to your current task.

You hear a loud cough behind you. A large and much-scarred man stares disapprovingly. He hands you a few royals. "Please keep silent about what you've seen," he warns.
fields.title: A Meeting

fields.description: You had hoped to catch him unawares by entering at night, but creaky floorboards doom your effort. Fortunately, his limp prevents him from catching you during your swift flight back down the stairs.
fields.title: A Light Sleeper

fields.description:
You silently creep into his room around midnight. Finding a few letters, you hold them up to the moonlight and read them carefully.

It sounds as though the adventurer is a trader in information. He has learned embarrassing facts about Patriarch Gol's grand-daughter, has predicted a rush on cotton stocks in Risapo, and has received early reports of a promising gold dig in north Talimar. Still, nothing in here implicates House Naper. Is he innocent, or just very careful?
fields.title: Suspicious Correspondence

fields.description: "Hey, there! Can I get you a drink? Well, if you aren't paying, kindly scram!"
fields.title: Too Visible

fields.description:
You would have missed it entirely if you had let your attention wander for even a few seconds. A plain-looking man in ragged but clean clothes comes to the bar and orders a drink, and you see him pass a small slip of paper along with the royals he gives to her.

The paper disappears in her blouse, and the man heads to the door empty-handed. You follow him back to the edge of town, where a carriage is waiting. No sigil is visible on the exterior, but the carriage's construction - burnished cherry panels, iron clasps that look plain but well-made - seems to imply that it is of Republic make. What would a Republic carriage be doing here?
fields.title: Foreign Agents

fields.description:
Temor sounds elated when you announce that the messenger is guilty. "I knew it! That boy always struck me as sneaky. Tell me, were you able to recover copies of the messages?"

You confess that you were not, and Temor's mood sours. "How am I supposed to convince the Patriarch that he's responsible if I have no proof? I'll be even more doomed than I am now. Keep looking, there must be more to find!"
fields.title: Insufficient Evidence

fields.description:
Temor is surprised at the identity of the culprit. "In all honesty, I thought he was a bit of a long shot. I never understood how a man with such limited mobility could have stolen a copy of my message. Tell me, were you able to recover it?"

You confess that you were not, and Temor's mood sours. "How am I supposed to convince the Patriarch that the adventurer is responsible if I have no proof? I'll be even more doomed than I am now. Keep looking, there must be more to find!"
fields.title: Insufficient Evidence

fields.description:
Temor flushes in anger. "How dare you besmirch her? Her, and my own reputation? I'll have you thrown in my uncle's dungeon!"

You quietly describe the exchange you witnessed between the barkeep and the foreigner, and Temor's rage quickly dissipates. He motions for you to leave the tavern, and the two of you return to his lodgings. Inside, he begins to pace, connecting the dots as he speaks out loud.

"I think I've made a huge mistake. I've known Misty for several years, and have always taken good care of her. When I'd received this assignment to cultivate dissidents within the Republic, I traveled through this town to see her, even though it was out of my way. Yes... I was, ah, unguarded after our meeting, and she certainly would have been able to look through my effects without my realizing. But why?"

A light appears in Temor's eye. "Ahhh... she must be a sympathizer! Many people born outside of House lineage are attracted by the foolish claims of the Republic, and believe that if they could only join it, they would be showered with wealth and prestige. All her declarations of loyalty to House Naper were a ruse. She is a spy, and we must bring her to the Patriarch!"

Temor rushes back to the tavern once more, but it is too late: Misty has gone. The tavernkeeper seems ignorant of what has transpired. "She saw you and that #MAN_WOMAN# walking for the door, then she turned pale and ran out the back. I hope she comes back soon, I can't serve all these drinks by myself!"

You receive a significant rewards from Temor before he rides back to the House. "You have my thanks for all your assistance. I will most likely be executed within a week, but at least my uncle will know the truth of what has happened. I will tell him of your loyalty to us; perhaps you will be able to serve him better in the future."
fields.title: A Mystery Solved

fields.description:
"Hmm... you look like the sort who can learn something quickly. Well, I've had my fill of the poachers in these parts! They think they can steal our Patriarch's game, and make me look a fool in the process! With your help, I may be able to put a stop to them."

He shows you how to safely disarm a leg trap by tripping its spring with a long stick. "Nasty piece of business, that... nobody would make such a thing out here, it must hail from some diabolical lair in the Kingdom. It's not all they have, either: watch out for deadfall boulders, deep pits with branches on top, and snares. Bring any traps to me, and I'll pay a bounty. I'll pay an even greater bounty for a trapper!"
fields.title: Patriarchal Permission

fields.description: By Korol! This snare is made out of some thin, flexible metal, not rope like a good, honest trap should be. You are forced to leave the rabbit in discomfort, and decide to return later with better tools.
fields.title: Uncuttable

fields.description: You snip open the snare and the rabbit hobbles out. You collect the snare and return it for your reward.
fields.title: Cut and Gone

fields.description: You hesitate in the moment you grab the stick, and pain fills your head. You wake up an hour later in the grass, disoriented but largely unhurt. It looks like the poachers have been here while you were unconscious and removed the evidence of their crime. There will be no reward for you today.
fields.title: A Close Call

fields.description: It's a close call, but you manage to leap away from the falling boulder in time. You collect the components of the trap and return them to the gamekeeper, who grunts his approval and hands over a few coins.
fields.title: Swift Moves

fields.description: You may be a little too cautious. After spending close to an hour scrutinizing individual beds of leaves, you turn around and walk back the way you came, wondering whether you have escaped harm or if you imagined the whole thing.
fields.title: No Signs

fields.description: Your suspicion proves correct: the trap is cunningly positioned close to a large tree, whose roots help cover its hole. You are too late to save the deer already inside, but you make note of its location and give your report to the gamekeeper.
fields.title: Deep Trouble

fields.description: You attempt to re-set some of the leg traps in new locations, but they keep snapping shut prematurely. How do the poachers manage to keep their own traps ready?
fields.title: Jumpy Trigger

fields.description: With a deft touch you manage to re-arm a dozen leg traps. You lay the traps in a nearly solid line crossways across a widely traveled path. If the poachers get here before the animals do, it's almost certain that one of them will step in it and get caught. You report your preparations to the gamekeeper, who enthusiastically endorses the plan and promises to keep alert for any sudden shouts.
fields.title: Baited and Waiting

fields.description: You easily slide the trap off his foot, but your knots for his wrists prove insufficient. Halfway to the gamekeeper, he punches you in the back of your head and makes his escape.
fields.title: Loose Knots

fields.description: You free the poacher's legs and then bind his hands together and lead him on a tether back to the gamekeeper's camp. The gamekeeper cackles with glee, and the poacher eagerly begins talking about his fellows' locations and movements. With luck, this whole episode will soon draw to a close.
fields.title: The Patriarch's Justice

fields.description: You attempt to rig a series of logs to fall from the treetops onto the men's tents, but lifting them that high proves difficult, and doing so quietly is impossible. The gamekeeper insists that you come up with a new plan.
fields.title: Plans Gone Awry

fields.description:
The gamekeeper is horrified by your plan, but you convince him that it's the only way to immobilize the camp's response. During the night, while the poachers are out hunting, you drag several carcasses to the camp. You lay a trail that should lead predators straight there.

Sure enough, soon after the men fall asleep, a sleuth of bears appears. They head straight into camp, and the initial cries of alarm are soon replaced with screams of pain. You wait until the situation sounds sufficiently desperate, then walk in, loudly banging together metal pots. The alarmed bears flee, leaving behind a mound of groaning poachers.

The gamekeeper arrests the ringleader, a sour-looking man who rolls his eyes at every mention of the Patriarch. Before taking him to the dungeon, the gamekeeper hands you a bonus, and promises to put a good word for you in with the Patriarch.
fields.title: Nature's Revenge

fields.description: He spies your interest, and approaches you with a proposition. "Patriarch Engoth has decided to build a new toll bridge here. We have secured the necessary funds, and now need to gather supplies. We'll pay handsomely for high-quality hardwoods and raw iron ore. You might try speaking with local woodcutters and miners to see if you can get a cut of the action. Here, have a few royals for seed money. You can pay me back later."
fields.title: A New Middleman

fields.description: The lumberjack won't cut you a deal, but rightly points out that you will save time by not needing to go to the market. You order the lumber to be held in your name until you sell it in turn.
fields.title: A Fair Deal

fields.description: You manage to win some concessions from the lumberjack: he'll give you a discount for buying in bulk, and he'll let you store the logs here until you send an agent to claim them. Good thing, you weren't looking forward to carrying them out yourself.
fields.title: A Lucrative Deal

fields.description: You feel like you're making progress in your negotiations with the foreman, but run into a wall when it comes to the question of transport. He insists that you pay for the labor to move the lumber to the bridge site. You grudgingly agree, and accept his payment in advance.
fields.title: Taken to Town

fields.description: The foreman appreciates your candor when discussing prices, and agrees to pay a reasonable markup in exchange for your assistance in transporting the lumber.
fields.title: Supplied

fields.description: The miner sounds amenable to finding a new buyer for his ore, but only if it pays as well as he can get at the market. You reluctantly pay him and take your stones.
fields.title: At Cost

fields.description: You give the miner a hand with his cart and chat as you approach town: you ask after his health, his opinions on the bridge, his thoughts on the war between Houses. Along the way, you casually mention that you are helping House Engoth buy supplies for their new bridge. On the spot, he offers you a substantial discount on the contents of his cart.
fields.title: A Discount

fields.description: The foreman gravely informs you that he has a limited budget to work with, and cannot offer the kind of price you want. You argue for several minutes, then spot another merchant coming up the road with their own cart in tow. You hurriedly finish the deal and agree to his original terms before your competitor arrives.
fields.title: Fungible Commodity

fields.description: You extoll the praises of your metal to the foreman: low in impurities, easy to work with, and, most importantly, available immediately. He sighs, and complains that he'll have to cut into his own pay to acquire this, but accepts your terms.
fields.title: Precious Metal

fields.description: You are horrified to discover that all able-bodied men and women in town have apparently made a pact to not accept less than seven royals per day to work on the bridge. Did the foreman already know about this? You gave your word to bring back a crew, so you grudgingly pay the full amount. The whole experience leaves you somewhat poorer, but you remain within the good graces of House Engoth.
fields.title: United Labor

fields.description: Rather than check in the usual locations for workers - the tavern, the thoroughfare, and the village green - you scout some spots off the beaten path. You find two strong women at the dry goods store, an idle farmer in his field, some off-duty guardsmen. They happily accept a few coins, and you send the motley crew off to their job.
fields.title: Diamonds in Rough

fields.description: The bakery can't finish cakes for another week. The seamstress refuses to work with the fiddler. The tumblers are nowhere to be found. You return to the foreman in defeat. Fortunately, it sounds like the Patriarch is occupied with other business, giving both you and the foreman time to finish your work.
fields.title: Organizing a Mess

fields.description:
You spend days lining up the festivities: fresh arch-shaped pastries, colorful streamers, a festive band, acrobats, even a tame bear! The Patriarch arrives on schedule and watches the show with great delight. He then cuts a ribbon in front of the bridge, ceremonially opening it to the town and the rest of the House.

The Patriarch summons you to his pavilion afterwards. "I have heard from my agent and his foreman about your assistance in creating this bridge. House Engoth thanks you for your dedication. Building something like this requires cooperation from many people, and individuals like you are essential to making sure that everything operates smoothly. I understand that you may have earned some small profit yourself while doing our work. You are entitled to keep it, and I will give you a small bonus as well, both to honor your past deeds and as a deposit for future tasks Engoth may have for you."
fields.title: A Fine Show

fields.description:
A traveling companion offers to keep watch over you during the night. She shakes you awake in the middle of a particularly unpleasant dream you've been having in which you were hanging from a cliff by your fingertips, desperately trying to claw your way back up. She stares at you in dismay.

"No doubt about it: you've been touched by ether. Or are touching it, I suppose might be the better way to put it. Your arms started twitching, and then those cups over there began moving towards you. You'd best keep this quiet; most people are frightened of etherists. If I were you, I'd try to find someone else with the affliction and see if you can get it under control. Hey, don't feel bad! Many of the best adventurers out there manipulate ether. If you can get through this, you could become the best of all of us."
fields.title: Pulling Forward

fields.description: You sit bolt-upright in the morning. Your body is sweating, but your mind is blank. You don't remember a thing.
fields.title: Drowsy Void

fields.description:
You slowly drift into consciousness, and realize that you're mumbling to yourself. You gently encourage yourself to keep talking and think about its import later.

"I can feel it better when I'm not trying to think about it. Maybe that's why it's easier in dreams. It's still there, though... I can feel it all around me. It's like I'm moving around in water, without the wetness or the weight. I've moved in it all my life, so I don't even realize it's there. But sometimes... if I try hard enough, I don't just feel it, I can pull it, and sense ripples in the ether..."
fields.title: Inklings of Ether

fields.description: Eggshells, crushed. Spare bedroll, unrolled. Nearby dog, spooked. What does it all mean? You require more study.
fields.title: Muddled Signs

fields.description: You carefully note the results of your experiments. Lighter-weight objects like eggs have moved a greater distance than heavier objects like your backpack. But even an enormous boulder that you could never move with your bare hands has shifted somewhat. It would seem, therefore, that when pulling at an object through the ether, your force is limited by the weight of the object; at higher weights, though, your force is only diminished, not eliminated. With enough time, could you move a mountain?
fields.title: Weights and Measures

fields.description: This is frustrating. Intellectually, you know that it must be out there, but you can't sense anything. The more you try to reach out and grab it, the farther it falls from your grasp.
fields.title: Nothing

fields.description:
The first hour passes in frustration; try as you might to sense the ether, all you can feel is the air around you. It occurs to you to consider that the air IS the ether. It isn't exactly the same thing, but it's a convenient fiction.

You blow out a steady breath, and feel the air ripple away from your face. You close your eyes and continue breathing. Next, you close your mouth. Somehow, the ripple is still continuing. It's no longer air, but the ether flowing away from your body. Gently, you guide the flow of ether into a stream. You realize that you can sense when this stream bumps up against a solid object. With enough practice, you can probably use this stream to manipulate such objects. This deserves closer study!
fields.title: A Faint Sensation

fields.description: "Ether is a string that ties all things together. Ether is the light from the stars. Ether is the sustained breath of the world." No, no, no... even as you write the words you realize they're more misleading than helpful. How can you hope to help others understand when you can't even explain it to yourself?
fields.title: Wrong, All Wrong!

fields.description: You aren't terribly happy with your attempt at explaining ether, but you feel like you got more things right than wrong. Ether isn't exactly an object, it's a medium. It isn't too helpful to describe objects as moving through the ether; instead, it's more like the medium grows denser or lighter in spots, and the energy from those changes can affect visible objects. You're pretty sure that, since all objects exist in ether, everything can both affect it and be affected by it, but humans are apparently unique in making efforts to deliberately change the ether.
fields.title: A Rough Draft

fields.description: After a week passes with no response to your letter, you're forced to conclude that they don't believe it worthy of a response. Perhaps your theories were wrong, or just not expressed correctly. Perhaps your next effort will prompt a more positive response.
fields.title: No Response

fields.description: After a week, you receive an envelope from the Kingdom. You break the unmarked wax seal to find a few royals and a brief note of encouragement. The etherist hasn't signed his or her name, but whoever they are, they encourage you to continue your studies and visit the lyceum in the future.
fields.title: A Cautious Reception

fields.description: Drat! Why can you move items with your mind when you aren't trying to, and not move them when you are? Perhaps next night's dreams will prove more productive.
fields.title: Motionless

fields.description: It seems to be working. For several nights in a row you set a bone several paces from your head before falling asleep; each day, it moves closer to you. You even manage to win a small bet with a stranger that you can move the bone without him noticing. He pays up, but you decide it's best to keep quiet about the ether for now.
fields.title: A Useful Show

fields.description: Hmm. It doesn't seem to have moved all night. Unless you somehow pulled it towards you and then pushed it back again. You'll need to keep trying.
fields.title: Stubborn Pot

fields.description: Yes! You wake up to find the stuffed pot only inches from your face. Not only that, but you also apparently dug up some nearby soil as well, revealing some semiprecious rocks underneath. This ether business may eventually prove profitable.
fields.title: Objects in Motion

fields.description: Glaring at the leaf seems to do nothing. It eventually falls, but only after a particularly stiff wind rips through the area. You feel fairly sure that you cannot take credit for that.
fields.title: Ineffective

fields.description:
You can sense fairly early on that you will be successful. You flag down a passerby and boast that you can predict when a leaf will fall. He offers to bet you six royals that you cannot, and you gladly accept.

You close your eyes, take a deep breath, and begin drawing ether into you. You point at a low leaf on the nearest branch and say, "That one will drop in ten seconds." Increasing the flow of the stream, you sense the leaf tugging in your direction. After ten seconds, you give a sudden jerk to the stream's flow.

The man gasps, and you quickly release the stream so the leaf will fall naturally to the ground. Both of you stare in silence at the ground. You smile and hold out your hand. "Six royals, was it?"
fields.title: Come Down

fields.description: You choose a distant field where you can practice unobserved. The first few minutes go smoothly: you practice pulling the sickle towards you through the fields, and also grab a few stalks of wheat successfully. After that, though, your connection with the ether seems to seize. You feel a sort of tiredness; not the tiredness that comes after a long day's walk, but the tiredness that comes when you're stuck in a boring conversation for too long. Try as you might, you can't make the ether flow any more. You slink away from the field before the farmer can reprimand your work.
fields.title: Mental Pain

fields.description:
You choose a distant field where you can practice unobserved.You practice pulling the sickle towards you through the fields, and also grab a few stalks of wheat successfully. You decide that the weight of the sickle is unwieldy, and focus on the plants. Much better. In fact... you close your eyes, broaden the stream, and feel a wide current of ether flowing through you. Instead of trying to grab the entire plants, you focus on the kernels on top. Sure enough, they are less tightly bound to the plant than the plant is to the earth, and you soon hear the satisfying sound of thousands of kernels of wheat gently falling to the ground.

You feel exhausted after an hour and make your excuses to the farmer, who pays you for your work and thanks your initiative in harvesting the grains.
fields.title: Thresher

fields.description: The needle flies through the air each time, alarmingly approaching your face at great speed before you grab it with your hand. After much pricking and bleeding, you decide to quit before your eyes are put at risk.
fields.title: Ouch!

fields.description:
You're gradually getting the hang of it. For some reason, you can't seem to move the needle away from you, but you can draw it towards you at any angle. By focusing on the head of the needle, you can grab the ether in front of it, and pull that ether into and through you; the needle follows in the ether's wake, much like a boat pulled downstream, and the thread follows the needle, much like a barge tugged behind the boat.

Examining the small finished square, you conclude that it will never be called pretty, but it is useful enough to fetch a few coins. Perhaps someone can find a use for it as a drab tea cosy, or a rough kerchief.
fields.title: Ethereal Art

fields.description:
You land two solid blows, then immediately feel the ground rushing up to meet you. The next thing you know, you're lying on the street with a throbbing head and boot marks on your backside. A sympathetic guardsman approaches you for commiseration.

"Congratulations are in order, I suppose. You've just had your first meeting with the Baird Brothers. They're three belligerent, obstinate, smelly creatures. Whenever they start brawling with each other, all the merchants howl because of the property damage; when we try to stop them, though, they gang up on us and lay folks flat. I'd recommend steering clear of them. Unless you're in the mood for a fight, of course. If you can incapacitate them a little, well, I suppose you'd be helping to keep the peace, and we do pay a little to our volunteer guardsmen. Here are a few coins for your first punches."
fields.title: Pounded

fields.description: Yet again, you find a Baird introducing you to the dirt. Apparently Martin doesn't even think you deserve a further assault after you fall; he continues along his path, no doubt coming closer to whatever mischief he intends to create.
fields.title: Slammed Down

fields.description: Martin seems so intent on his destination that he doesn't even realize you mean him harm. He roars in rage as your first blows fall about his head. He continues to turn around so he can land a powerful punch, but you follow his circle and remain safe from harm. You spot the other Baird brothers running, and decide to strategically withdraw before they arrive.
fields.title: A Mighty Blow

fields.description: You land the first blow with ease, but run into trouble quickly as Glen rebounds with furious fists. He swats the wood aside whenever you try to jab him, and lashes out when you pull back for a swing. You eventually toss it at his head and make your escape when he ducks.
fields.title: Beaten Back

fields.description: Glen lands several solid punches on your chest, but you develop an effective rhythm for your own assault: minimal movement of your hands, focusing the force of each blow on the tip of the beam. It doesn't matter terribly much where the strike lands, since each beat staggers him a little. Glen eventually lets out a gasp that signifies either surrender or unbridled rage, and you leave him to his pain.
fields.title: Beat Down

fields.description: You don't remember the fight well, but acutely note the swelling of your head afterwards. Sympathetic onlookers declare that you gave as good as you got. There's just a lot more of Carl that needs hitting.
fields.title: Maced

fields.description:
You warily circle around while Carl eagerly swings his mace at your head. After several misses, you spot an opening, and bring your own weapon down on his arm. He lets out a howl and strikes your chest, though you lean back enough to avoid most of the force.

The fight ultimately ends in a draw, but since Carl had to summon his brothers at the end, most onlookers agree that you triumphed.
fields.title: Powerful Struggle

fields.description:
She holds up a hand for silence as you approach, and you remain motionless for several long minutes. Swiftly and smoothly, she raises her bow, notches an arrow, and lets it fly. A passing deer lets out a gasp and collapses into the dirt.

The huntress notes your impressed reaction, and while you help her truss the deer, she offers to give you some advice on your own archery skills. She lends you a short bow and suggests that you start by practicing on stationary targets, and then move on to the slower animals. "Stay away from deer," she advises. "Poaching is a crime against the House, and not a risk someone like you should take."
fields.title: A New Mentor

fields.description: You manage to hit the haystack a few times, but more of your arrows fall wide of the mark. The huntress observes your form and makes a few suggestions: keep your feet as far apart as your shoulders, bend your knees slightly, draw back until your hand rests below your ear. Your last few shots seem more accurate.
fields.title: Wide Miss

fields.description: You listen to the huntress's advice, then start practicing your shooting. Your arrows usually strike the haystack, and sometimes even land close to the spot you were aiming for. She encourages your progress.
fields.title: Solid Landing

fields.description: If the scarecrow were a real person, you're fairly sure that he or she would be laughing at you by now. You've somehow loosed an entire quiver of arrows, and only managed to hit its edges once or twice. The huntress advises you to focus on lining up your shot instead of focusing on your target, and encourages you to keep trying.
fields.title: An Embarrassing Display

fields.description: Any shot you aim at the scarecrow's head goes wide, but those you aim at the chest all land with satisfying thunks. The huntress congratulates you on your progress, adding "Once you're comfortable with this, you will graduate to more mobile targets."
fields.title: Feathered Flight

fields.description: Your arrow misses the leader. A dozen angry eyes peer up at you and the huntress, feet paw at the earth, and tusks are lowered threateningly. You turn to her to suggest running, and see that she has already made her escape. You quickly follow.
fields.title: Angry Pigs

fields.description: The boar lets out a powerful squeal as your shaft perfectly hits the mark. The other pigs scatter, leaving the prize to you and the huntress. She gives a small nod. "That was well shot. I'll take this to town; here's a portion of the price I expect to fetch. I'm happy to continue advising you, but it looks like you're now ready to start practicing on your own, perhaps against even more dangerous game."
fields.title: Pointy Trophy

fields.description:
One of the miscreants runs into your outstretched leg and flies headlong into the road. His friends abandon him while the soldiers swarm around their new prisoner, shackling him and invoking the Patriarch's justice.

The captain nods gravely at you. "We appreciate your assistance. Bandit activity has increased lately; they seem to sense a growing risk of war between Houses, and think that their activities will go unpunished. With the armies being called to the borders, fewer of us can patrol the roads and keep our travelers safe. Here, take this sword. The next time you see a highwayman, this will make more of an impression than your foot. We'll be in the area for some time, so summon us and we'll pay a bounty for any criminal you help us apprehend."
fields.title: Deputized

fields.description: You try to follow the progress of the fight, but everything moves too quickly for you to understand. The soldiers have the advantage of numbers, yes, but how are they triumphing even when matched one against one? Why do they fight without shields? How are they avoiding the daggers? Shrugging, you walk away from the melee, pondering what you have seen.
fields.title: Whirling Blades

fields.description: You watch the soldiers closely. They show a great deal of skill, and put forth surprisingly little effort for the results they achieve: a captain thrusts forth his blade only a few inches instead of rearing back for a big blow, and those few inches are sufficient to bring his opponent to his knees. They fight without shields, but are able to parry aside outthrust daggers; the clubs seem to pose a greater challenge, but the soldiers are nimble on their feet and can step back to avoid those swings. Seeing that the fight is well in hand, you continue on your way. Perhaps next time you will join in.
fields.title: Precise Strikes

fields.description: The fight goes well, but with little help from you. The brigands you face easily knock aside your blade, and even when you strike accurately you can't seem to penetrate their armor. Still, at least you survived with your own skin intact, and you learn a little by watching your comrades.
fields.title: Bloodless

fields.description: You find yourself facing off with one of the brigand lieutenants. You deflect his dagger thrusts with your blade, and your riposte cuts deeply into his leather vest. He soon throws down his weapons in surrender, and the captain pays you a small bounty after the fight.
fields.title: Hack and Slash

fields.description: The brigands hear you coming from far off and are ready for you. They attempt to surround you, but you manage to put your back against the merchant's cart. Unfortunately, this leaves you without an escape route. Your sword proves no match for their array of clubs, and only the timely arrival of a patrol saves you.
fields.title: Beaten

fields.description: You are pleasantly surprised to see the merchant come to your aid against the foes. Two against four is still a challenge, but you make the most of it: standing back-to-back, you and he manage to keep your enemies at bay. Your frequent jabs draw occasional blood, and more importantly discourage them from closing into a more lethal range. Meanwhile, the merchant wields his own longsword with decent skill, weaving it back and forth in a wide arc. When the patrolling soldiers arrive, they finish the fight and pay you a bounty, to which the merchant adds a few coins of his own.
fields.title: Valor

fields.description: You lost
fields.title: Lose

fields.description: You won
fields.title: Win

fields.description: The recruiter gives you some money for initial expenses. "You have no official relation to House Naper, you must understand, but you will be doing the Patriarch's work and so long as you carry out his will you will be welcome in our lands. You may keep any valuables you find on the brigands, but do not steal from our people or we will hunt you down. While in Naper, please keep alert for any activity on the border of Gol. I've heard rumors of war, and worry that if a conflict starts there it may spill into our own House."
fields.title: A New Land

fields.description: The recruiter draws you a map of the best routes to Naper and encourages you to come when ready. "You have no official relation to House Naper, you must understand, but you will be doing the Patriarch's work and so long as you carry out his will you will be welcome in our lands. You may keep any valuables you find on the brigands, but do not steal from our people or we will hunt you down. While in Naper, please keep alert for any activity on the border of Gol. I've heard rumors of war, and worry that if a conflict starts there it may spill into our own House."
fields.title: A Later Call

fields.description: It's hard to know from day to day whether you're improving, but you think you're getting a little stronger.
fields.title: Time Passes

fields.description: You walk out the door on your own two feet, head held high. You have suffered and triumphed over adversity. Along the way, you have grown wiser, and less likely to make the same mistakes again.
fields.title: A New Chapter

fields.description: Your family's fortunes have fallen somewhat, but their pride remains high. Father teaches you how to handle a sword properly like a true nobleman. Both parents speak frequently about the wonders the world has to offer, and impress upon you the value of a keen mind and close friendships.
fields.title: A Privileged Childhood

fields.description:
Huzzah! You've taken your first step on the way to becoming a citizen of Skal.

You'll notice that you have a certain number of blank pages available. Each time you make a choice in your story, the outcome is written on a fresh page. Once you run out of pages, your story will pause, but it doesn't end. New pages will be added for your character over time so you can continue your story.

Click below to proceed.
fields.title: The First Page in Your Story

fields.description: You work hard from the day you are strong enough to lift a rake. As you grow older, you begin to shoulder more and more responsibility on the farm. Birds and wild animals constantly threaten your crops, and you become an expert at shooting them down before they can do harm.
fields.title: An Honest Start

fields.description: Your parents always seem busy, but make time to play with you and introduce you to life outside your home. You become a favorite among your little friends, always leading in any activity. Once you grow old enough to count, your mother begins taking you on business trips with her, and you grow familiar with the intricacies of bookkeeping.
fields.title: Cultured Living

fields.description: No parent ever willingly brings their child anywhere near a battlefield. Your parents are equally determined that, should your own course ever take you near a fight, you should be as prepared as possible. Thus, from a young age you receive training in a variety of weapons, including swords and maces. Your father cautions you to never strike in anger; your mother teaches you to draw quickly when in danger.
fields.title: An Exciting Childhood

fields.description: Your father teaches numbers and sums, while your mother teaches the history of Skal. Education is viewed as a luxury among most people of your background, and you develop an appreciation for studying. As the years pass and fewer children come to the school, you help your parents as they turn their focus to tutoring for wealthy and powerful families.
fields.title: Early Lessons

fields.description: Over the years, you develop close friendships with others like you: children who need to make their way in the world without the reliable support of adults. This informal community of "mice" exists in most major towns, and helps newcomers learn the skills of survival. You become adept at remaining unseen from those who mean you harm, and learn the best ways to snatch some food or royals when a grown-up's back is turned.
fields.title: Life Lived Hard

fields.description: Your stick may not have a blade, but you wield it like a sword. Friends learn to treat you with caution when you're leading a charge.
fields.title: A Budding Fighter

fields.description: Few books can be found near your home. Of these, most are devoted to practical matters of crops and accounts. A few, though, speak of older ages and the founding of the Kingdom; fewer still offer hints of the Ether, suggestions for interacting with the medium of the world. You don't understand all that you read, but believe it will become useful someday.
fields.title: Deeper Knowledge

fields.description: Adults might scoff at the sight of two kids tussling on the ground, but such kids are learning important lessons about dominance and power. You grew adept at using your hands to grasp or strike an opponent, and entered adolescence with a sure sense of self-reliance.
fields.title: Top of the Pack

fields.description: Hours and days spent wandering outdoors help you develop a keen sense of direction. You learn to navigate by sun and by stars. You start to recognize the tracks of various wild animals, and become skilled at tracking them down.
fields.title: Orientation

fields.description: One must learn to move silently and hide in shadows if one wishes to win at hide-and-seek. You find the least-traveled areas near home, practice squeezing into small places, and step so carefully that your shoes make no sound at all.
fields.title: Neither Seen Nor Heard

fields.description:
Congratulations! You have purchased your first item in Skal. Some items like this map will open new choices and storylines for you. Other items will boost your stats, and still others will help you fight more effectively should you choose to enter battle.

The traveler points out a few nearby locations of interest: the main highway, a crossroads where she encountered bandits, the nearest other village. She wishes you luck on your journey.

With your new map in your pocket, you are ready to take your next steps towards true independence.
fields.title: Map in Hand

fields.description:
The furrier praises your hard work and keen selection, and pays you for the armful you collected.

Notice that making this choice has provided you with a reward of a royal coin and also a small increase in a stat. When you collect 10 points in this stat, it will increase to the next level.
fields.title: A Fine Haul

fields.description:
This year saw a bountiful grape crop so there isn't much room for margin, but you manage to earn a little from your day of selling in town.

Notice that making this choice has provided you with a reward of a royal coin and also a small increase in a stat. When you collect 10 points in this stat, it will increase to the next level.
fields.title: Sweet Success

fields.description: A very large boy wins in the end, but you advanced quite far in the competition and earned some enthusiastic cheers from the crowd. You receive a consolation prize and an invitation to return tomorrow.
fields.title: A Good Showing

fields.description: You manage to beat the other competitors and win the contest outright. For your efforts you receive a small purse of Royals and the heartfelt enthusiasm of the spectators.
fields.title: Victorious!

fields.description:
Their purses are a little lighter, and your own pocket a little heavier. Surely the good this will do for you outweighs the small inconvenience to them.

Notice that making this choice has provided you with a reward of a royal coin and also a small increase in a stat. When you collect 10 points in this stat, it will increase to the next level.
fields.title: Redistribution of Wealth

fields.description: You spin tales of woe and hardship that would make even the hardest heart shiver. You smile, nod, and thank profusely as a coin is dropped into your makeshift begging bowl.
fields.title: A Pitiful Sight

fields.description:
You have committed the map to your memory. You can now confidently travel onward. Your story is about to begin...

You have learned your first new destination. In order to continue in your story, you will need to travel to The Nearby Countryside. You can do this by clicking Travel on the menu above.

You will gradually discover many new places as your adventures continue in Skal. You may find some in maps like this one, but will also learn more by speaking with other people or pursuing quests. Some locations may charge a fee for entry or require a special type of item, like a horse or a ship.
fields.title: A Way Out

fields.description: You interview several people who witnessed the most recent attacks. You spot a few signs of the cougar near the edge of the forest, but quickly lose track of the animal. It may have walked down the stream, or taken to the trees. You study the available signs closely, and hope that another attempt will prove more successful.
fields.title: Eluded

fields.description:
For a crazed creature, the cougar is a remarkably subtle beast. It has prowled through these woods for its entire life and knows every nook. Your eyes are sharp, though, and you pick out the subtle clues that point you in its direction.

You return later in the day leading a posse of farmers who enthusiastically destroy the dangerous animal. They thank you profusely for keeping their homes and families safe. As a reward, they offer you a long cloak the color of a deep, mossy green. This cloak will help you succeed in future hunts.
fields.title: Caught!

fields.description: The recruiter seems to disapprove of your young age, and asks you to prove yourself in a practice combat with him. Using training swords, you spar lightly for several minutes, but you quickly realize that he is holding back and remains unimpressed with your talent. "Kid, I'd hate to pick you up only to see you die in our first battle. Keep practicing, and I'll gladly take you when you show me that you can survive out there. Come back if you ever want to spar again."
fields.title: Drummed Out

fields.description:
You spar with the recruiter, who seems suitably impressed by your sword-wielding prowess. He hands you a uniform and a short blade, introducing you into Naper's ranks.

Your first two weeks of duty go smoothly: you patrol the major highways with a small squadron of soldiers, scaring off bandits. On the fifteenth day, you are called to action: a rogue captain from House Hansa has crossed the Tanalga river, intending to loot the settlements nearby. 

The battle that results is brief and bloody. Your company surrounds a farmhouse that the captain's renegades have fortified. Archers on the upper floors have a clear shot at the surrounding farmland, making a frontal assault extremely costly.

You suggest a radical solution to your commander: launch flaming arrows into the farmhouse to flush them out. He grimaces but acknowledges that this will be the safest route for your group, and gives the order. Less than an hour later the enemy captain is in chains, his dreams of glory quashed.

You receive a decoration for your service, and at the same time are discharged from service. "The heirs to this property are furious over the loss of their building. They have demanded punishment, but I won't see you thrown in prison for the role you've played. May you go in good fortune, and I hope House Naper can repay the debt in the future."
fields.title: Tour of Duty

fields.description: You recognize two of the women who you suspect are couriers in this network. You follow them from a distance through busy city streets and out the gates, but once in the countryside they quickly spot you, and soon after they manage to lose you by cutting through the forest. Your stealth has served you fairly well, though, and a future attempt may succeed.
fields.title: Seen

fields.description:
Two women seem to handle the initial movement of goods from the small village of Folls south to the border with Naper. You manage to conceal yourself on their cart, and soon depart with them on the road.

Your presence remains undetected for most of the day, until one of them unexpectedly checks on the bag of goods in back. Rather than throw you out, she appraises you coolly. “The people I work with would prefer that I slit your throat. Truthfully, though, if you could remain hidden from me for this long, you should be able to help us move this cargo across the border. Do this for me, and I'll let you keep your life.”

Sensing a good deal, you gratefully accept, and under cover of night the three of you silently bypass the border guard. When dawn breaks, they reclaim their cargo and head off. You overheard whispers of “Tummon”, which must be their destination.

Besides your life, they also give you the gift of a pair of soft leather boots. These will help you move even more quietly the next time you need to travel unnoticed.
fields.title: Remained Unseen

fields.description: Convincing the prospectors to let you do the leg-work proves to be the easy part. Much more challenging is negotiating a fair price for their gold down in Folls. You eventually manage to recoup your initial investment, but with no profit. You'll need more practice to turn this into a prosperous business.
fields.title: Break Even

fields.description: You develop good contacts among several of the prospectors, and negotiate a fair price that takes into account the service you're providing. The gold merchants in the trading village of Folls are used to the giddy enthusiasm of successful prospectors and so are unprepared for the rational savvy you present. You skillfully play the buyers off one another until you have secured a tidy little profit for yourself. Flush with the success of starting your own business, you spend - or, you insist to yourself, invest - your earnings in a simple but impressive ring made from the very gold you sold. Wearing this sign of success will convince others that you are a merchant to be reckoned with.
fields.title: A Valuable Service

fields.description: You spend several days walking up and down the roads, carefully copying every example of script that you can find onto your parchment. You see repeated characters from sign to sign, but cannot discern the meaning of the markings. You resolve to continue collecting more evidence in hopes of discerning the secret.
fields.title: Evidence Without Theory

fields.description:
You gradually amass several precious pages of signage. The breakthrough comes when you find a character ¬ repeated twice in a row. This marker is located a little ways north of the Naper city of Tummon, and you hypothesize that it corresponds to the modern letter "M". This proves quite plausible, and working from that supposition, you quickly crack the code of the signs. Doing so allows you to reconstruct the names of several places that seem to have vanished entirely in the last several hundred years.

You write down your discoveries into a message that you send to the scholars of the Kingdom. They write back quickly and courteously; apparently this "mystery" has been solved many times, but rarely by someone from the hinterlands of the Houses. They encourage you to visit the lyceum in the future, and enclose a meditative amulet that, they claim, will help you focus in your future studies.
fields.title: Ancient Words

fields.description: You struggle mightily against the oak, straining with all your force against the trunk, beating its limbs with your own. It avails you nothing. If there's any consolation, the other participants similarly fail to uproot their own trees. Everyone shakes hands, and you agree to reconvene the next day and try once again.
fields.title: Ironwood

fields.description:
Few can believe their eyes when the mighty tree comes slowly crashing down, pulled there by the force of your powerful blows. The rest of the harvest festival is given over to celebration of your mighty deed.

The local elder proudly awards you the prize: a mighty hammer. "The blows of your mighty fists are strong enough already. I fear to imagine what will happen to enemies facing the fury of your hammer!"
fields.title: The Great Rip

fields.description: You stride into Folls, confident and ambitious. Soon your name will be known throughout the land!
fields.title: The Glorious Morning

fields.description: You stride into Tummon, confident and ambitious. Soon your name will be known throughout the land!
fields.title: The Glorious Morning

fields.description:
Without a moment to lose, you start grabbing more buckets. You develop an unspoken arrangement with the well-dressed man: he stays at the well and fills them while you rush between the well and the blaze, dousing the wood as quickly as you can. 

Despite your best efforts, the fire continues to spread. Gradually, more people from town come running to assist. The fire's growth is checked once a dozen are helping, and slowly they beat back the blaze. The house is ruined, but the nearby structures have been saved.

Relieved, the villagers drift to the nearby tavern to celebrate and steady their nerves. The man who first helped fight the fire shakes your hand. "I am grateful for your assistance. My name is Trindan, and I fear that this fire was no accident, but a foul plot. Please meet me in the tavern, and we can discuss further."
fields.title: A #MAN_WOMAN_CAPITAL# of Action

fields.description:
"Fire! Fire!" you holler as you run through the streets. Startled eyes meet yours, then look beyond to the wisps of smoke rising into the sky. Smiths drop their hammers, shopkeeps abandon their stores, everyone you see recognizes the threat and runs to help combat it.

By the time you return to the scene, the blaze is largely under control. A few nearby buildings have been damaged but escaped serious harm; only the initial house has been wrecked beyond repair. You help douse the last few flames and congratulate the rescuers. Relieved and exhausted, they retire to a nearby tavern for celebration.

The man who first helped fight the fire shakes your hand. "I am grateful for your assistance. My name is Trindan, and I fear that this fire was no accident, but a foul plot. Please meet me in the tavern, and we can discuss it in more detail."
fields.title: It Takes Many

fields.description:
You quietly lurk in the shadows and see the fire grow larger and larger. The well-dressed man spends far too much time running back and forth between the well and the fire, and the blaze swiftly grows beyond control.

The general alarm is raised after a minute, but by then it is too late for the house. The entire adult population of the town eventually arrives and manages to contain the destruction to the nearby area, but still, a substantial portion of the town has burned, and many of these buildings will never be habitable again.

Disappointed, the crowd disperses, with many people retiring to the tavern to drown their disappointment in drink. You overhear the initial responder talking to some others within the crowd: "This was no accident. Someone set this fire, and they may set more if we don't find them. My name is Trindan; find me in the tavern and we can start our hunt."
fields.title: Opportunity in Chaos

fields.description: Trindan buys you an ale. "Everyone is happy that we put out the fire, but nobody believes me about the blaze being set deliberately. Either that, or they suspect me of starting it. Not that I can blame them; I only arrived in town a few hours earlier, and I'll admit that the timing is suspicious." He takes a deep drink from his flagon and stares at you for several moments. "I can't say much right now, not without proof, but I think that this fire was created specifically in order to cause chaos and raise tension. The men who I followed to this town could have started it, but I haven't been able to learn why they would do so. Once I have gotten further in my investigations, can I count on you to help me bring them to justice?" This story will continue in the future. In the meantime, pursue any of the other scenarios that interest you in town or in the countryside, and wait for Trindan to return later.
fields.title: The Start of an Investigation

fields.description:
Trindan's rage cools when he sees you. "Please excuse my outburst. I just received word from my… employer that he wouldn't send the support I'd asked for." He turns back to his visitor. "Please tell Father that I will take matters into my own hands, and hope to receive his assistance soon."

You and Trindan take a seat and he informs you of his findings. "I have been following three men for the last month. A suspicious record of villainy seems to accompany them wherever they go: they arrive in a town, then some disaster takes place, and a few days later they leave. Three times it has been fire; once the city gates were left open and brigands looted the shops; once a dam was broken and half a village inundated. They claim to be timber merchants, but I have yet to see them actually purchase any lumber."

Trindan describes them to you: "The three of them are all quite short, with pale skin and red hair, and usually wear green vests with brown trousers. Their leader always wears a black cap and carries a flail - quite an unusual weapon for a merchant, you'll agree. I would have expected them to leave by now; our interrupting of their arson must have kept them from causing the degree of chaos they intended. They must be laying low for now and waiting for an opportunity to strike again."

He sighs deeply. "Unfortunately, they must have recognized me, and have been careful to avoid doing anything suspicious when I'm nearby. I had hoped to receive assistance in this task by now, but apparently other saboteurs are causing similar problems in other villages, so our other agents are currently busy. Can you please help me find evidence? We need to know who they are, who they serve, and what they hope to accomplish. I will pay you for your aid. Please return to me once you learn more."
fields.title: Shadow the Saboteurs

fields.description: The trail grows cold quickly. You must have missed a clue along the way. Perhaps they will be less careful next time.
fields.title: Vanishing Trace

fields.description: You follow them to a meeting in a secluded forest glen where they meet two other men, dressed much like themselves. You're close enough to catch a few words of their conversation, which you write down. After they leave, you enter the glen yourself, and find some coins on the ground. Interesting. Some of these have markings that you don't recognize.
fields.title: A Secret Meeting

fields.description: You weren't able to manipulate the lock's pins successfully, and a moment of frustration caused you to break the pick. You slink back downstairs, vowing to try again later.
fields.title: Snap!

fields.description: A minute of patient tinkering with the lock grants you access to the trio's room. Inside, you find a partially-written letter addressed to someone in Gol. Most of the letter's contents are unfamiliar, but you copy them down; perhaps Trindan will be able to decipher its meaning.
fields.title: Illicit Entry

fields.description: The man is staggered but remains conscious. He hollers for help, and you flee before his compatriots arrive.
fields.title: A Glancing Blow

fields.description: The man never saw you coming, and crumples silently. Moving quickly, you rifle through his pockets. You find a few coins with unfamiliar markings on them, and some scraps of paper written in an unusual script. After taking the evidence, you quickly leave before anyone can ask awkward questions.
fields.title: Whack!

fields.description:
Trindan meets with you in his well-appointed lodgings. He looks carefully over the papers and trinkets you have collected, compares them with his own notes, and gives a grunt of satisfaction.

"Well done, #TITLE_NAME#. This evidence indicates that our three suspects are operating under orders from someone within House Gol territory; these markings show the crest that Gol used before the rise of the Kingdom, a symbol that these days would only be recognized by scholars and the inner family of Gol.

"Since you have done this service for me, I should properly introduce myself. I am Trindan of House Hansa. Patriarch Hansa is my third cousin, once removed, and he relies on me to seek out threats against Hansa. Several months ago, I noticed an unusual amount of activity in House Engoth and House Naper on the border of Gol. Such spying and sabotage often precedes an invasion. A war between these Houses would create a great deal of unrest. It would certainly harm Hansa's trade, and depending on how such a war progressed, it could drag us into the fight as well.

"That said, I have not yet been able to determine the reason for such attacks. Gol is a weaker house than Naper or Engoth, and would lose a war against either one, let alone both. The targets they have struck hurt the people of those Houses, but do nothing against their armies. So what purpose do they serve? What do these men hope to accomplish?"

Trindan sits silently in thought for several moments. "I can now prove the connection between these saboteurs and House Gol, but we need to prove a motive before we can ask Hansa to intervene. You have been most helpful so far. Here is a reward, and also a request. Please find the place where their handlers are hiding. I'll provide what assistance I can. If we can solve this mystery, you'll gain the eternal gratitude of House Hansa."
fields.title: Find the Masters

fields.description: The defiant man spits in your eye, says awful things about your lineage, and offers to die rather than betray his secrets. You'll need to find another way to make him open up.
fields.title: Uncooperative Witness

fields.description: The agent remains defiant, but seems somewhat relieved to have someone other than Trindan to speak with. Although his speech remains guarded, he lets slip a few pieces of information that may help point you in the right direction.
fields.title: Slips of the Tongue

fields.description: The leader's skill with his flail would frighten even the most skilled swordsman. After only a few seconds, you wisely decide to retreat before he does permanent harm.
fields.title: Swinging Menace

fields.description: You call out an agent in the street. Whatever his background, he seems honor-bound to accept the duel. His blows come quickly and fiercely, but you manage to parry the strikes, and after several powerful swings of your blade he surrenders and begs for mercy.
fields.title: Blade's Edge

fields.description: You spend hours poring over the symbols, but they mean nothing to you. You rub your eyes in frustration before turning in to sleep. Perhaps tomorrow will prove more insightful.
fields.title: Resisting Analysis

fields.description: This seems to be a substitution cipher. There is some mechanism they use that you don't entirely understand that shifts the cipher for each word. By focusing on a few specific words, you eventually develop a reasonable translation that fits and is internally consistent. Some of the words include names of nearby places. Interesting. This should help you narrow down the places where they may be hiding.
fields.title: Partially Decrypted

fields.description:
You piece together all the scraps and fragments of data you have received so far. While there's no single conclusive statement, you are reasonably sure that the saboteurs are hiding in a remote wooden cabin on a hill overlooking the Tanalga river. 

You travel to Trindan's dwelling to share your discovery, but see no sign of him. His servants have left, and the captive has vanished from the basement. How curious. You resolve to head to the countryside and scout their hideout yourself.
fields.title: Finding a Cabin

fields.description: Trindan arrived here before you did and met a gruesome end. It looks like he surprised the men inside, several of whom sit slumped and very dead around a table. You recognize the capped leader of the saboteurs. It appears that he inflicted fatal wounds upon Trindan before he was stabbed through his stomach. Trying to ignore the stench of death, you search through the cabin and the bodies' clothing. You find several letters hidden under a wardrobe;. Unlike the ones you found earlier, these are written in plain text without encryption. You focus on the most recently dated letter: I'm grateful for all the support we've received for this enterprise; as unpleasant as this business is, our employers have paid handsomely, and we should be able to retire and escape whatever cataclysm is coming. To answer your question bluntly: yes, I do worry about the chaos we're creating. I know that our masters are members of House Gol, but in all honesty, the fact that they're hiring us makes them traitors to their own House. Though they have never indicated that they are working for another, I imagine that they are most likely in the service of yet another faction. Perhaps House Forcan? They would have much to gain if Gol fell into a war along its western border. Stunning news indeed. Whatever the agents' plots, it looks as though Trindan was able to stop this cell before they could carry out their immediate plans. Judging from this letter and Trindan's earlier musings, though, there may be more cells active, carrying out who-knows-what schemes. At last, you look through Trindan's personal effects. He didn't carry anything that would have betrayed his own affiliation to House Hansa, but you do find a cryptic reference to a cave in House Engoth. It looks as though Trindan had his own masters with their own hideout. If you can find the cave, you may be able to establish contact with Hansa and pass along news of what has occurred.
fields.title: A Disturbing Sight

fields.description: Hansa agents have not traveled this way for several weeks, but you find enough signs of their crossing to discover their trail, which leads you to the cave. Inside, you find a sheaf of papers from the House, bound with what appears to be Trindan's seal. Near these papers you discover a map of Tummon, with a star marked around a particular house. Nearby he had scrawled Password is Tanalga. Are the house's residents friends or foes? You will need to be prepared when you make a visit.
fields.title: Trindan's Own Hideout

fields.description: A soft-spoken poacher in fur leggings indicates that he knows a cave where foreigners have met in the past. He leads you there. Inside, you find a sheaf of papers from the House, bound with what appears to be Trindan's seal. Near these papers you discover a map of Tummon, with a star marked around a particular house. Nearby he had scrawled Password is Tanalga. Are the house's residents friends or foes? You will need to be prepared when you make a visit.
fields.title: Trindan's Own Hideout

fields.description:
Several surprised faces greet your entry. "Who are you? Did Trindan send you?"

You question them, and learn that these men were sent from House Hansa to aid Trindan in his raid on the agents from Gol. They react with shock to the news that he proceeded without them and perished in the assault.

"Such madness. He must have learned that they were planning a strike against the town and felt that he needed to act immediately to stop it; that's the only explanation for the risk he took. We'll report these events back to the Patriarch. Regardless of who was ultimately behind these plots, it's clear that Gol will be a source of danger for some time, and we need to be prepared."

The men pay you a small reward before departing. "Should you ever travel to House Hansa, please report to the Patriarch. We'll want to make sure that all of Trindan's effects are provided to his nearest surviving family."
fields.title: Hansa Supporters

fields.description:
Green Haron meets you in his "office," a cramped cellar underneath the mill. "Have you heard of Mad Sigar? Crazy man, obviously. He was born here a century ago, inherited vast wealth, and became convinced that Ether was trying to kill him. Decided he could trick it by building the most convoluted, nonsensical dwelling ever, so it couldn't find him. Bought up blocks and blocks of houses around his own, built tunnels and passages between them all, turned it into a huge warren."

Haron coughs fitfully before continuing. "He finally died last year, and his heirs want nothing to do with the mansion. His will was quite a bit smaller than you'd expect of a wealthy man like him, though, and we think he hid the remainder in that death-trap of his. We'll be sending crews in at night to look through and grab what treasures we can find. You'll earn a share for your contributions. See you soon, and stay alert if you want to see daylight at the end!"
fields.title: Mad Sigar's Mansion

fields.description: Try as you might, you can't seem to locate the hinges. This door must be hung in an unusual way.
fields.title: Stubborn Entry

fields.description: It takes some exploration, but you eventually locate the hinges. Two of them, close to one another. With some extra force you snap the door open. Inside the gang discovers a few eccentric knickknacks worth several royals. There are many other closets like this around that should offer similar treasures.
fields.title: Unorthodox Solution

fields.description: Sigar must have hired locksmiths as crazy as himself. The orientation of the pins and tumblers seem completely wrong, and you have a hard time imagining what the key to open this lock would even look like. You eventually surrender before the lock damages your pick or your mind.
fields.title: Twisted Mind

fields.description: Sigar must have hired locksmiths as crazy as himself. The orientation of the pins and tumblers seem completely wrong, and you have a hard time imagining what the key to open this lock would even look like. You eventually surrender after the lock breaks your pick in what seems like a deliberate fit of pique.
fields.title: Badly Twisted Mind

fields.description: The lock's mechanisms seem deliberately obscure and bizarre, but patient prodding of your pick eventually coaxes it open with an alarming snap. The gang swiftly rushes in, grabs what they can find, and exit before the guard patrol returns. You accept a modest cut from the proceeds.
fields.title: Unique Design

fields.description: You manage to clear the way, but mostly by accidentally setting the traps off and taking the damage upon yourself. The gang happily loots a new room, and take pity upon you when dividing the rewards.
fields.title: Pincushion

fields.description: Shick! You carefully trigger a pressure plate that sends spikes thrusting out of a garish mosaic wall. The gang gingerly steps around the spikes while you continue pressing the plate, and return with some valuable baubles.
fields.title: Suspended Spikes

fields.description: You have become good at working in tight spaces, but it's still difficult to locate triggers in pitch black. Particularly the best way to find the triggers is by touch, and touch easily results in a belch of flame. You tumble to the bottom and land in a bruised heap.
fields.title: Singed Hairs

fields.description: Taking your time, you gingerly ascend a few inches at a time, jamming your feet in position against the shaft walls while your hands carefully brush the stone around your head. You locate a few ingenious triggers that would be activated if the dumbwaiter ascended in the incorrect orientation. Cautious application of a file succeeds in whittling down the reach of the trigger. Now the gang will be able to ascend without fear of their lives. They gratefully pay you an advance on the next discovery of treasure.
fields.title: Climber

fields.description: You've heard stories about hidden passages behind bookcases. They make it sound easy: just tilt a book and the wall opens up. They never describe which of the thousands of books you need to tilt, though. You give up after a frustratingly unproductive hour.
fields.title: Mystery Books

fields.description: You methodically move through the library, lifting books and examining the backs of the shelves. You soon narrow your search to a particular case with a unique wood grain; searching further, you eventually find a wooden keyhole concealed within a knot. Upon opening the lock, the case slides back easily on oiled casters, revealing a room of treasures beyond.
fields.title: Answers in Literature

fields.description:
Sigar seems to have spared no expense in protecting the heart of his mansion. He guarded the door with clockwork locks, multiple deadbolts, a particularly clever system requiring water to open, and no fewer than ten poisonous traps. You patiently crack one obstacle after another.

Green Haron leads the way inside. The haul is rather impressive: some pre-Kingdom artwork, various golden artifacts, some books that look particularly precious and rare. The room also holds the sort of junk that you would expect an insane recluse to accumulate: mounds of scratched-out paper, dirty dishes, empty bottles, mummified plants. It takes hours to sort the goods from the chaff.

The next day, Haron pays out your share and shakes your hand enthusiastically. "Well done, #INFORMAL_NAME#. We might never have found our way inside if not for you. I'm proud to call you one of our Gang. Feel free to operate within my city as you see fit; none of our enforcers will trouble you. If you ever get into trouble, just send word, and we'll do our best to break you out."
fields.title: The Richest Haul

fields.description:
Sigar seems to have spared no expense in protecting the heart of his mansion. He guarded the door with clockwork locks, multiple deadbolts, a particularly clever system requiring water to open, and no fewer than ten poisonous traps. You patiently crack one obstacle after another.

Green Haron leads the way inside. You motion for the rest of his gang to go ahead, then slam the door behind the last of them. Shouts of angry indignation arise! Their fists pound angrily and futilely against the unyielding door. You re-set all the locks and the traps you can before silently making your exit.

You return to Haron's hideout underneath the mill. With his entire gang incapacitated, it's little work to clear the room of all its valuables. It looks like Haron was lying about the size of the take and not paying you a fair share. Well, that obligation is now repaid, and with interest.
fields.title: Turning Tables

fields.description:
By now you've learned the routes of the city guards quite well, so it's trivially easy to follow them back to their headquarters and ask to speak with the chief guard. You're evasive about how you came by this information, and he's so excited by the prospect of catching a ring of thieves red-handed that he doesn't press you for details.

On the night of the robbery, you lurk on the street until you see Green Haron and several of his gang members enter the mansion. You signal the guards, and minutes later you are greeted with cries of shock as they apprehend the thieves. Haron manages to escape through a hidden passage, but they capture him the following day.

The guard presents you with a reward for services rendered. They offer to declare a day in your honor, but that would lead to some awkward conversations. You content yourself with several firm handshakes and promises of future assistance.
fields.title: Unexpected Ally

fields.description:
Some focused inquiries eventually lead you to the Group for the Exploration of Manse Sigar. The founder briefs you on the mansion's history. "It was built by a wealthy man named Sigar. He wasn't Ether-sensitive, but was fascinated by the Ether, perhaps unhealthily so. He devoted his life and considerable fortune to buying all adjacent properties and linking them together into the complex you see today. He designed it as a lure and a trap for etherists: many of the doors and such inside can only be manipulated via the ether, and he hoped to trick those with skill into revealing themselves."

He hands you a roughly-sketched map and an iron key. "This will let you into the main section, the original house. Other members of our Group are busy creating proper maps of the interior and cataloguing the artifacts we find for the heirs. We have need of an etherist to open some of the ways, and will pay you for any assistance you provide."
fields.title: A Curious Mission

fields.description:
You chat amiably with your companions in the carriage. It sounds like there's little love lost between Engoth and Naper, although nobody worries that actual war will erupt. The patriarchs are content to insult one another and compete in building the most lavish dwellings.

After crossing the border, you alight from your transport and bid farewell to your companions. You find all the lumberjacks after a few days of travel and deliver your messages as promised. It must have contained good news, because the lumberjacks insist upon giving you several scrips good for future deliveries of wood.
fields.title: Subsidized Travel

fields.description: You're still young, and your body is very resilient. You feel much better the next day.
fields.title: Fitter, Happier

fields.description: Your roommates hardly snore at all, and you wake feeling much refreshed.
fields.title: A Decent Sleep

fields.description: You sink contentedly into a deep, soft, extremely comfortable mattress, and swiftly drift off to sleep. You feel very refreshed in the morning.
fields.title: A Great Sleep

fields.description: Ahhhh…. you hadn't realized how hungry you were before starting, but your body was certainly ready for more sustenance. Your injuries seem to be getting a little better, too.
fields.title: A Warm Glow

fields.description:
Crimson guards whisk you through the corridors of the Great House, into the very hall of the Patriarch. He stares at you with interest from the Chair as you describe your time with Trindan. Once you finish, he leans forward and gravely delivers a commendation.

"Hansa mourns the loss of Trindan. I did not know him as well as I would have liked, but saw his loyalty and skill proven time and time again when he pursued our enemies and thwarted plots against our House. He left behind a widow, who would certainly value the personal effects that you have recovered. Please visit her when you are able."

Chancellor Ernon, the Patriarch's loyal advisor, hands you a Writ of Hansa Passage. "In recognition of your service to our House and to Skal in thwarting the actions of those who intended to sow chaos, I hereby declare you a friend to Hansa. From this time forth, you may present this Writ upon entry to Ettan and pass our gates without paying any toll."
fields.title: A Fatherly Commission

fields.description:
Poria, Trindan's widow, embraces you at her home's entryway. "Trindan was a great judge of character, so if he trusted you in his mission, you must be a good #MAN_WOMAN#. I will show you that same trust now."

She takes you to her parlor and continues while you nibble on a plate of bread and cheese. "Trindan built a large network of informants, and some of them have continued sending reports to this house. They say that the flow of visitors from Gol to Engoth and Naper has slowed in the last few weeks, but recently strangers have begun to arrive here in House Hansa. I worry that they mean to cause the same kind of destruction in our own land. The Patriarch won't pay attention to my warnings; he thinks I am distraught and paranoid, and has asked Trindan's agents to stop reporting to me. Please convince the agents to resume passing their information along to me so I can convince the Patriarch of the dire danger he faces!"
fields.title: Danger at Home

fields.description: This agent has been evading detection for longer than you've been adventuring. She spots you, approaches, and dashes off before you can recover.
fields.title: Double Back

fields.description: How interesting. She seems to be meeting with both the city guard and a clique of highwaymen. Surely she intends to betray one group to the other, or is revealing each group's secrets for her own profit. The agent goes pale when you casually mention this to her, and she agrees to pass her findings along to Poria.
fields.title: Triple Crossing
