fields.description: You're a passable blade, but the agent has made some powerful enemies. She escapes while you're holding them off. Not a word of thanks!
fields.title: Left in the Lurch

fields.description: As it happens, the agent needed some muscle to bring in the prime suspect for another investigation she was making. In appreciation for your service, she agrees to report to Poria when she learns more about the suspicious migrations from Gol.
fields.title: A Hired Blade

fields.description: "Thank you for seeing me. That fool Patriarch has laughed of my concerns for too long, and I fear that now he will suffer from it. Last week a delegation from House Gol crossed the border. An assassin accompanies them! They will arrive at the Great House any day now to request their audience with the Patriarch. You must stop them before they strike!"
fields.title: Subtle Blade

fields.description:
The bannerman sees you coming, and reacts as though he was expecting trouble. His own sword whips from the scabbard, parrying your initial blow. His robes prove an encumbrance when fighting so close to other people milling around, and when he trips, your blade quickly extinguishes his life.

The chamber swarms with guards running towards the sound of the struggle. This proves fortunate: the assassin wasn't working alone after all. The other members of the honor guard drop their own banners, bring out their weapons, and charge towards the Patriarch's chamber doors.

Breaking down the doors, they reveal a startled Patriarch seated on his great chair, with only two bodyguards for protection. One of the killers almost reaches him before he is brought down by a well-aimed armor from behind. Guards swarm the chamber, and after a while you can no longer see the Patriarch.

Finally, the last of the assassins lies slain. They could have provided very useful information if taken alive, but seemed determined to avoid capture. Who could inspire such loyalty in killers?

Chancellor Ernon holds a hurried conference with you afterwards. "Have you seen the Patriarch? He disappeared during our struggle, and I haven't been able to turn him up. This is a disaster! The leader of the delegation claims that he had nothing to do with it, that the bannermen were all strangers to him, but this is a move that smacks of a prelude to war. We must find the Patriarch to rally our troops before it is too late!"
fields.title: Bloody Struggle

fields.description:
You sneak around the honor guard, place your back against a wall, then unsheathe and strike in one lightning-quick motion. The blow rebounds! He must have expected trouble if he layered extra armor underneath his robes. He seems to have expected trouble, because he doesn't react with surprise, instead letting out a roar and drawing his own blade. Before he can finish turning, though, your second strike has landed on his unprotected head and finished him.

The chamber swarms with guards running towards the sound of the struggle. This proves fortunate: the assassin wasn't working alone after all. The other members of the honor guard drop their own banners, bring out their weapons, and charge towards the Patriarch's chamber doors.

Breaking down the doors, they reveal a startled Patriarch seated on his great chair, with only two bodyguards for protection. One of the killers almost reaches him before he is brought down by a well-aimed armor from behind. Guards swarm the chamber, and after a while you can no longer see the Patriarch.

Finally, the last of the assassins lies slain. They could have provided very useful information if taken alive, but seemed determined to avoid capture. Who could inspire such loyalty in killers?

Chancellor Ernon holds a hurried conference with you afterwards. "Have you seen the Patriarch? He disappeared during our struggle, and I haven't been able to turn him up. This is a disaster! The leader of the delegation claims that he had nothing to do with it, that the bannermen were all strangers to him, but this is a move that smacks of a prelude to war. We must find the Patriarch to rally our troops before it is too late!"
fields.title: Bloody Struggle

fields.description:
You hold a hurried and quiet conversation with the captain of the guard. You need to exaggerate a few details to impress the seriousness of the situation on him. At last, he walks over to the bannerman. The assassin had watched your conference, and when the captain is within reach, he brings out his sword for an attack. Bellowing for support, the captain kills the bannerman with a furious blow.

The chamber swarms with guards running towards the sound of the struggle. This proves fortunate: the assassin wasn't working alone after all. The other members of the honor guard drop their own banners, bring out their weapons, and charge towards the Patriarch's chamber doors.

Breaking down the doors, they reveal a startled Patriarch seated on his great chair, with only two bodyguards for protection. One of the killers almost reaches him before he is brought down by a well-aimed armor from behind. Guards swarm the chamber, and after a while you can no longer see the Patriarch.

Finally, the last of the assassins lies slain. They could have provided very useful information if taken alive, but seemed determined to avoid capture. Who could inspire such loyalty in killers?

Chancellor Ernon holds a hurried conference with you afterwards. "Have you seen the Patriarch? He disappeared during our struggle, and I haven't been able to turn him up. This is a disaster! The leader of the delegation claims that he had nothing to do with it, that the bannermen were all strangers to him, but this is a move that smacks of a prelude to war. We must find the Patriarch to rally our troops before it is too late!"
fields.title: Bloody Struggle

fields.description:
The note is from the Patriarch! 

"Dearest #TITLE_NAME#: I owe sincere thanks to you and widow Poria. I feel a fool for ignoring her advice. Were it not for your timely intervention, I would surely lie dead now. As it stands, I have decided to flee the Great House and rule from a secret location. I do not know how many traitors Gol may have planted within my House, and may not be so fortunate the next time they decide to strike.

"Please do me the great favor of protecting my person against further threats. You have proven yourself a loyal friend to Hansa in the past, and I hope you will continue to aid me now. I have asked Poria to share any intelligence she discovers with you, and hope that you will take whatever actions prove necessary."
fields.title: A Surprising Turn

fields.description: The good news is, you've learned that these were definitely more assassins. Poria will be pleased to hear that her intelligence is accurate. The bad news is, they didn't take kindly to your intimations of violence, and decided to beat you in response. They also got away, and continue to pose a threat.
fields.title: Pushed Back

fields.description: They put up a brave showing at first, but after you demonstrate your seriousness on the first "merchant," the rest surrender. They claim to actually be traders, but admit that a hooded man in Gol paid them an exorbitant sum of money to poison the Patriarch. They turn the poison in question over to you and leave, swearing to never enter Hansa again.
fields.title: Bop on the Head

fields.description: Well, that wasn't too successful. The merchants don't even notice your traps: the carriage rides right over them without incident. Hm. You'll need to review your construction technique. You're out the coin for the caltrops, too.

Success! The swiftly-moving carriage plows right over the caltrops, injuring the horses and sending the wheels flying. The merchants tumble out in a heap. While they're disoriented, you quickly disable them with some swift blows to the head and search their belongings. Aha: a vial of poison! You send word for one of Poria's agents to deal with the groaning would-be killers.
fields.title: Broken Feet

fields.description: You find a nice perch with clean sight lines, but the dim moonlight makes aiming difficult. After your first arrows fall harmlessly to the ground, the group quickly scatters, and begins methodically advancing under cover towards your tree. You quietly leave while you can.
fields.title: Falling Arrows

fields.description: You climb a tree at dusk and wait for their approach. Just enough moonlight illumines the glade to reveal the approaching convoy. Your first arrow takes the leader in the leg, and your second lands in his arm. They panic, believing themselves under attack from a much larger force, and retreat en masse.
fields.title: Aerial Strike

fields.description: Like all cautious travelers, the killers have set up a watch system. Sneaking up on guards is never easy, and seems virtually impossible in broad daylight.
fields.title: Alert Watchers

fields.description: The camp has set watchers around the perimeter, but you manage to make it in by carefully observing their own observation: what direction they're facing, how often they leave to check another entry to the camp, whether they continue to watch while drinking water. You calculate an opening and silently run into the camp while their attention briefly lies elsewhere. Once inside, you cut open their canteens of water, dump their provisions onto the ground for animals to discover, and untie the horses from their tethers. They'll find it difficult or impossible to continue their search in this condition.
fields.title: Infiltrator

fields.description: You can feel the solid wooden mass of the lever, but can't actually move it. Are the metal bars of the portcullis interfering? Apologizing to the group, you promise to try again some other time.
fields.title: Motionless

fields.description: The metal grille of the portcullis proves a bit of an obstacle at first, but you channel a flow through one of the openings, reach out to the lever, then loop the return flow back through another opening. After less than a minute the lever pulls towards you, and the portcullis rises up. The group collectively gasps in pleased astonishment, and pays you as promised for services rendered.
fields.title: Rise Up

fields.description: You send several tentative tendrils out through the ether, but are stopped cold by the door each time.
fields.title: Blank Face

fields.description: The door certainly looks solid, but after you close your eyes and set to tentative exploration through the ether, you become increasingly sure that you can still get through it. There are tiny holes everywhere, in this and in all other objects: our senses tell us that they are solid, but the ether flows through all of them. With increasing confidence you reach out, through the door, and locate the thumbturn on the other side. You then need to solve the opposite problem of treating the thumbturn as a solid object and not a floating collection of particles. Your own band of ether aligns properly, you focus intently, and are rewarded with the satisfying turn of the lock. The cheers of the mappers is only an extra benefit.
fields.title: Always a Way In

fields.description: You are able to easily move the small pebbles filling the gaps of rubble, and soon have things moving around easily. A little too easily, and without any clear direction. By the time you're done, the barrier has gotten a little shorter but expanded outward in both directions, making progress even more difficult than before.
fields.title: Landslide

fields.description: You start small, jarring a few interior pebbles loose. Once they are in motion, you provide a gentle extra nudge, directing them towards the back of the turn, then smoothly arcing around on the other way out. Some of the larger stones naturally begin sliding in the same direction. You help these along as well, and before long even the largest boulders have rolled farther into the corridor. The mapping team heartily claps you on the back before stepping farther along to continue their exploration.
fields.title: Cascade

fields.description: You can tug on the walls and floor, and manage to trigger a few of the traps, but at such a slow pace that it would take far too long to make sure the entire room is safe. The disappointed team still gives you a token payment in thanks for your effort.
fields.title: Lack of Coverage

fields.description: Focusing on the far end of the room, you start setting a circular loop of ether into motion. You focus and slowly move it along the floor, then up the walls and the ceiling, until you are sure that it has pulled at every exposed surface in the room. Along the way you are treated to a variety of crashes, booms, pops, and other sounds indicating the deployment of traps. After several minutes of silence, the mapping team creeps back around the corner. "Excellent show, #TITLE_NAME#! You are making the world safe for historians!"
fields.title: Wide Tug

fields.description: You lie in wait for the thieves that night. When they arrive, you begin pulling at various objects - a broom, a painting on the wall. They flap around somewhat alarmingly, but the thieves seem unfazed.
fields.title: "It must just be a draft"

fields.description: You conceal yourself and wait for the thieves to arrive at night. You put on a spectacular show for them: a suit of armor approaches menacingly and then lifts its helm to reveal nothing inside; a knife slices apart a loaf of bread, butters each slice, and serves each thief a a plate; a basket of cherries is emptied and the fruits arrange in midair to read SIGAR SHALL HAVE YOUR SOUL. Screams and slamming doors end the night most satisfactorily.
fields.title: "Run away!"

fields.description: You discover that you can shift the tiles around through ether, but it only seems to change the look of the picture. You have yet to discover the secret to opening the wall.
fields.title: Inscrutable

fields.description:
After hours of experimentation, the solution comes to you in a flash of inspiration. Sigar had crafted this wall to ensure that only someone skilled in ether could open it. That means that the key isn't the tiles facing you, which anyone could manipulate. The solution must lie on the other side of the wall.

You reach out through the wall and explore. Sure enough, there's a mirror image of the mosaic on the other side. Almost a mirror, at least; several tiles that are immobile on your side are in other positions on the far end. You nudge them around until they precisely match the orientation that you see.

There's no audible sound, but when you press on the wall, it easily slides forward. The society of mappers erupts in cheers. Pouring through the door, they discover a vast library, filled with historical records, genealogies, memoirs, and more from Sigar's ancestors, going back hundreds of years. After several minutes excitedly exploring the library's contents, the leader approaches you and enthusiastically shakes your hand.

"Absolutely marvelous! We might never have discovered this room if not for you. Even just completing our map would have taken years. Here, take this - we're not a rich group, but you deserve whatever we can spare. I'll spread word to other people of culture and learning and let them know of your great skills."
fields.title: Bonanza

fields.description:
The traveler cackles as you hand over your royals. "Best of luck! I'm sure I'll be cursing myself after you find the trove for yourself!"

You look at the map. As the traveler described, it's badly faded, with no writing visible. You can just make out the shapes of several mountains, trees, rock formations, and other symbols. No compass  directions or borders can be seen. It will take some time to make this discovery.
fields.title: The Search Begins

fields.description: You spend the day wandering through nearby trails, across fields, over hills, crossing rivers, but can't find any new locations that look like those on the map.
fields.title: Coming Up Empty

fields.description: There! That, in the distance… the angle makes it look a little wrong, but if you were to approach it from the other side… yes, that's it! You confidently mark the new area on the map. You're closer to finding the treasure.
fields.title: A Fresh Discovery

fields.description: You're fairly sure you're in the right area shown on the map, but everything here looks like overgrown wilderness. If there ever was a path here, it's long since gone.
fields.title: No Route

fields.description: Sure enough, some methodical examination manages to turn up a long-abandoned pathway. You mark its location on your treasure map. One step closer!
fields.title: A Faint Trail

fields.description:
The woman arrives and begins conversing in a hushed tone.

"I know who you are, #TITLE_NAME#. Temor wrote to me before he left to receive judgment from his uncle. He told me that you have... particular skills that could help our cause. I am a friend to House Tandan, but they fear what I have to say, and so have been keeping me from the Great House. Someone like you, whose face they won't recognize, could get inside and deliver certain messages for me. You won't only be paid well, you'll know that your actions will help keep House Tandan strong in the years to come. I'll contact you soon with items for delivery."
fields.title: Infiltrate the Great House Tandan

fields.description: The guards at the gate have spotted you, and send a minder to make sure you don't do anything funny. You need to leave before you can properly examine the area.
fields.title: Suspicious Presence

fields.description: You spend some time along one of the walls, getting a feel for the entrances and exits that will be available to you. This will come in handy when you need to actually go inside.
fields.title: Thorough Casing

fields.description: The captain's eyes narrow when you proffer a hand filled with royals "Can't you see there are people watching?" she hisses through clenched teeth. "Where did Yalene find people like you? Come back later!"
fields.title: Gauche

fields.description: You ask the captain about the repairs to her dress armor, subtly slipping the coinpurse into her pocket as you talk. She gives the barest hint of a wink before sending you on your way.
fields.title: Handoff

fields.description: You manage to reach Gellar's quarters without any trouble with the guards, but a maid encounters you while you're trying to get in the door. She raises a fuss, and you make a swift exit through a convenient window.
fields.title: Discovered

fields.description: You arrive at Gellar's large and sumptuously decorated quarters. A satchel on an endtable holds many messages, which seem to have only recently arrived and all of which are still sealed. You locate the one with a matching seal and swap it out for your own.
fields.title: In and Out

fields.description: You are trying to melt the wax on the missive when Gellar's chamberlain enters his room. He summons the guards while you are stammering out an explanation. The guards unceremoniously throw you out of the Great House.
fields.title: Caught in the Act

fields.description: You avoid Gellar's chamberlain and use a candle in the room to soften the wax on the seals of the two messages. The one you were instructed to burn contains a report on recent troop movements in the Kingdom, south of the Tandan border. The one you're placing is similar, but reports larger numbers and places them in a different location. Interesting...
fields.title: Affairs of State

fields.description: You are moving a wardrobe aside when you feel a blade prick the back of your neck. "What are you doing here?" demands a cold voice. The captain of the guard arrives to take you into custody before he can do permanent harm, but you are thrown swiftly out of the Great House.
fields.title: Gellar Interrupts

fields.description: You hear a man moving in the next room, and conceal yourself inside a wardrobe until he leaves. Afterwards, you're able to tip the wardrobe slightly to one side and place the note underneath. Nobody will find this unless they're looking very hard.
fields.title: Well Planted

fields.description: You plant the note, but a painting on the wall catches your eye. It shows a woman in armor pointing her sword towards a town on a hill. The woman looks almost exactly like Yalene. The title under the painting reads, "Kingdom Commander Laying Siege."
fields.title: A Familiar Face

fields.description:
You easily find your way to Gellar's quarters. His eyes narrow when you walk in the door. "You look familiar. Who are you, and what are you doing here?"

You explain everything to Gellar: the previous work with Temor, the contact from Yalene, the switched documents and planted notes. You expect him to be angry, but he seems excited. "This is excellent news! Yalene is clearly an agent of the Kingdom seeking to manipulate our politics. My father has ignored my calls for war, but he'll never stand for such brazen interference in Tandan's sovereign affairs. At the least he'll finally cut off our diplomatic relations with the Queen."

Gellar leaves you alone for several hours while he presents your evidence to his father. When he comes back, he hands you a sizeable purse. "Understand that we could easily throw you in the dungeon for your actions, but Tandan wishes to reward those who show it favor, late though it may be. Remember who your friends are, and be careful in your future dealings with the Kingdom! They're a tricky, manipulative lot, dreaming of lost days of glory and constantly scheming to regain hegemony over all of Lok. We may call on you in the future to help combat the Kingdom threat."
fields.title: Security at Home

fields.description:
You feign the affect of a panicked messenger, yelling, "Please, I must see the Patriarch immediately! It is a matter of greatest importance!"

Patriarch Tandan receives you soon in his hall. He stares at you impassively as you deliver your tale, then frowns at the mention of Gellar's supposed involvement. "Gellar's irrational hatred of the Kingdom is no secret, and I find it hard to believe that he would hide such schemes from me. Still, we must determine whether what you say is true." 

Tandan orders the guards to search Gellar's chambers. They return with several sheets of paper that the Patriarch reads with clear fury. "I owe you an apology. These documents clearly show that Gellar was not only spying within the Kingdom, but had hired private mercenaries to start a war. Such actions are utterly foolish! I had hoped my son would grow out of his bloodlust, but it seems clear that he is without hope. I will remove him from succession and ensure that a wiser son will succeed me instead. Gellar himself must go into exile where he cannot interfere with Tandan policy."

The Great House is thrown into an uproar; most respect the Patriarch's decision, but Gellar has clear loyalists who passionately defend him. You slip out of the hall in the confusion, shed your costume, and report to Yalene. She is elated: "You have changed the course of history, #TITLE_NAME#, and we all owe you thanks. Please, take this reward. You have probably earned an enemy in Gellar, but you also have a powerful ally south of the border. We may meet again."
fields.title: Hierarchy Shake-Up

fields.description:
"Ah, I'm glad to see an outlander here! We were just discussing how we needed a fresh face to represent our petition to the Patriarch. I'm afraid that most people find trade policy terribly boring, but it's literally the lifeblood of a country - without trade, there's less work, less wealth, and more suffering."

The merchant representative points at a map of Lok. "Much of our industry here in Risapo depends on fine materials that we acquire from the Kingdom island Soronin. However, for generations Tandan has refused to allow Kingdom ships to dock in this port. Instead, Soronin ships its goods to Kingdom territory on the mainland, where it is then carried overland at considerable expense to our borders. That means more taxation, more overhead, pricier goods for everyone and less trade. In short, it's terrible!"

You receive a purse of coin. "I am hereby hiring you to lobby the Patriarch on our behalf. You probably won't be able to get an audience with him at first. I suggest talking with the various stakeholders in town and at court. Convince them to support a reform of policy. Once enough people get behind it, the Patriarch will be inclined to give you a fair hearing. Best wishes!"
fields.title: Shaping Trade

fields.description: Everyone you see appears far too busy with their cargo to spare time for an interview.
fields.title: Time Is Money

fields.description: A new ship has docked this morning and most merchants appear particularly busy, but you convince them to spare a few moments to speak with you. They generally favor the proposed reform to allow Kingdom ships to dock directly at the port, even with the extra strain it would place on port resources. They observe that not only would this approach avoid extra tariffs from multiple border crossings, but would also avoid the problem of brigandage. Merchants and other commoners would benefit from cheaper and more reliable sources of goods.
fields.title: The Favor of Trade

fields.description: "Pfaw! And why should Tandan allow Kingdom captains in her ports, I ask you? Little better than pirates, the lot of them! No, let them keep to their islands and us to the continent where we can profit properly!"
fields.title: Over Board

fields.description: The captain initially appears skeptical, but you gradually win her over with the prospect of fresh horizons to explore. "All my life has been spent running the routes north of Risapo, but that's the territory all the other Tandan captains sail as well. If we had clear access to Soronin... well, I might be able to get the jump on my competitors and carve out a new niche for myself. Very well, if anyone asks, I'll tell them that I favor opening the port to those royal-worshiping conquerors."
fields.title: Smooth Sailing

fields.description: The first words have barely left your mouth before the men begin yelling in outrage. They invoke the dead of the Unity War, the bravery of their ancestors fighting for liberation, the bad manners and shifty tendencies of Kingdom men and women. You silently leave when they begin drunkenly singing Tandan battle songs in unison.
fields.title: Angry Mob

fields.description: The mob begins shouting as soon as you mention the trade changes, but you shout them down in turn. They eventually listen as you explain that allowing cargo vessels will pose no military threat to Tandan; that cutting down on overland routes will free the Patriarch to deploy his troops to more useful locations; that this move could lull the Kingdom into a false sense of security before Tandan strikes them down in a glorious war. They let out a lusty cheer and soon are chanting "Down with the Kingdom! Open the Ports!"
fields.title: Placated

fields.description: "Oh, really? What, do you expect me to celebrate your attempts to destroy my livelihood? Our system has worked for generations and kept both countries at a healthy distance. Why don't you ask Talimar to open their ports instead?"
fields.title: Icy Reception

fields.description: The Kingdom traders rightfully fear for their comfortable position, but you successfully appeal to their sense of patriotism and love for their countrymen, both in Tandan and back home. You observe that two countries who openly trade with one another rarely war on one another. You leave as they start humming Kingdom ballads.
fields.title: Persuaded

fields.description: Each functionary you visit shunts you off to another office. After a full day, you have yet to meet one person of importance. Frustrating.
fields.title: The Run-Around

fields.description: You secure an appointment with a minister who listens patiently to your spiel. "Yes, I have been hearing a great deal from various people about the benefits of allowing direct access to Kingdom vessels. It will mean more paperwork for me and my department, of course, but it may be worthwhile just to placate those people. It's ultimately the Patriarch's decision, of course, but I won't stand in your way."
fields.title: Words in the Right Ears

fields.description: The Patriarch listens patiently to your argument but appears bored by the entire topic. When you finish, he refuses to make a decision, but asks one of his aides to gather opinions from the staff. He invites you to return later.
fields.title: Averted

fields.description:
The Patriarch seems surprisingly engaged in this potentially dull topic. He even interrupts a few times to ask questions, several of which are actually relevant. When you finish, he nods in approval.

"You make some excellent points. The current policy is a legacy from the time when Tandan and the Kingdom regularly fought over our borders, and we had every reason to expect a sneak attack from sea. While our relations remain cool, there's no reason to expect an outbreak in hostilities any time soon, and this change could even help avoid future threats of conflict. It will displease some members of my own family, but you have convinced me that we must allow more free trade with the Kingdom."

The next day, the merchants of Risapo hold a banquet in your honor, presenting you with a certificate of honor and a bonus for your fine work. "Who knows what changes this will cause? You've made the world a much more interesting, and hopefully more profitable, place for all of us. Our commercial brothers and sisters in the Kingdom are likely just as pleased; you should visit them sometime and receive thanks from them as well."
fields.title: A New Day

fields.description: You had thought that this was an area that one of the map's routes ran through, but perhaps not… you don't see any deliberate markings that would indicate someone was here before you. Either this is the wrong place, or such signs were lost with the passing of time.
fields.title: No Signs

fields.description: Most people leave trailsigns by blazing trees. Such marks would have disappeared long ago, so you focus on the areas outside of the forests. You discover a curiously deliberate-looking vertical pile of rocks, and a hand-sized etching in the side of a boulder. Either individually might mean nothing, but seeing both relatively close to one another convinces you that you're on the right trail.
fields.title: Saw the Sign

fields.description: It looks like you were right - there are definitely some signs of earlier passage here. Unfortunately, the signs are too faint for you to follow far.
fields.title: A Lost Trail

fields.description: Judging from the broken tree branches, campfire detritus, and discarded or lost articles of clothing, many people have searched this area before you, some of them quite recently. You must be getting closer to the treasure. Or at least the place where everyone thinks the treasure lies.
fields.title: Historic Passage

fields.description: You do see some clues that other people may have been here, but no signs of digging, or other ways to help narrow your search.
fields.title: Undisturbed Earth

fields.description: You see evidence of spadework in several nearby locations. Whoever dug here did so long ago, and most of the holes have since filled in with new vegetation. This area might be useful for further exploration.
fields.title: Holes

fields.description: You dig four good-sized holes. None of them hold any treasure, ancient or otherwise. Perhaps you'll have better luck next time.
fields.title: Coming Up Empty

fields.description:
Your alert eyes spot a twisted bit of metal lying near a large, flat rock. The iron looks quite old and tarnished; it could date from the time when the treasure was first buried.

The rock lies unusually on the ground as well, with a top that's totally flat and a bottom that look scalloped. You suspect that the rock was flipped at some point. That's enough evidence for you to begin digging.

You heave the rock over, take out your shovel, and set to work. When the pit is as deep as your waist, the soft sounds of dirt change to the muffled thump of metal striking wood. There's something down there!

Some more digging reveals the outlines of a chest. After excavating, you carefully bring it back up to the surface. You smartly knock the lock off with your shovel's blade and lift open the lid of the chest, to the loud complaining of its rusted hinges.

Well! That's quite an impressive haul! Certainly not the entire wealth of House Forcan - that tale must have grown in the passing - but likely the savings of a powerful branch within the family. The currency is pre-Kingdom, stamped with the face of a man with a pinched face, probably Patriarch Forcan. Such coins were actually outlawed during the primacy of the Kingdom, but you should be able to convert them to royals for their worth in gold. 

Whistling happily, you scoop up the treasure and fill your pockets. What a marvelous day!
fields.title: The Grand Prize

fields.description:
You feel a sense of foreboding as you approach the cabin. This feels eerily similar to the place where Trindan met his demise. A lone horse is tied up outside. He's still breathing heavily; whoever rode him must have just arrived.

Before you can knock on the door, you hear a loud shout. You rush inside and witness Chancellor Ernon drawing his blade on the Patriarch. Hansa seems surprised but not stunned, and brings forth his own sword. His eyes flick towards you. Ernon turns to see who's behind him, and the Patriarch lunges forward with astonishing swiftness, stabbing Ernon through the back. Ernon cries out and collapses to the floor.

Hansa's eyes have grown wild. Running a hand through his hair, he exclaims, "All this time, Ernon was working for them! Here I thought I was protecting him by concealing my whereabouts, when all along that was the only thing saving me. I only summoned him here after I decided that it was past time to send a delegation of our own to House Gol. We can no longer continue without knowing whether their Patriarch intends to start a war, or if other elements in his government are at risk."

Patriarch Hansa mounts the chancellor's horse and prepares to ride back to Ettan. "Please meet me in the Great House as soon as you are able. I must decide whether Hansa needs to go to war."
fields.title: Second Salvation

fields.description: Since you have taken the pressure off the agents' work in fighting the assassins, they have the time to follow up their own leads on the Patriarch's whereabouts. They find records about a little-used cabin that the previous Patriarch used when hunting game. It looks like Ernon, the Patriarch's chancellor, has begun sending his own messengers there recently. They draw you a map to the cabin's remote location.
fields.title: Secret Seat of Power

fields.description:
Patriarch Hansa meets you in his chambers. The vast room is utterly deserted other than the two of you. He seems to have recovered from his ordeal and appears cordial, but you detect a burning anger from inside.

"These must be dark days when I cannot trust my own second in command, and rely on a stranger for rescue not once but twice. I won't be able to repay you for saving my life, but let this be a start: from this day forth you shall be known as Agent #INFORMAL_NAME# of House Hansa.

"I have also rewarded Poria, who has surpassed even the high standard set by her late husband. All of Hansa's intelligence apparatus now reports to her, and I feel certain that we will be protected against future incursions from Gol.

"Despite all this bloodshed, though, it feels that we are still no closer to discerning who lies behind this threat or what they seek to accomplish. Gol is a weak House, and neither Poria nor I can imagine what they could possibly gain by starting a war against Naper, Engoth, and Hansa. We agree that some more sinister agenda may be afoot, and we need to determine its source before risking outright war.

"Therefore, I commission you, #TITLE_NAME#, to visit xxx, the seat of power in House Gol. Take this signet ring; it authorizes you to speak in my voice. Talk with Patriarch Gol. We have met in the past to discuss trade, and I found him a fair if reticent man. Share whatever evidence you feel is prudent, but do not tip our hand unless you see an opportunity for gain. I wish you the best of fortune, for all of our sakes."

(Note: You can review your available titles on the Profile screen. Additional titles will unlock as you continue to progress through Skal. Many characters will refer to you by your selected title, and this is also how you will appear to other players of Skal.)
fields.title: The Great Commission

fields.description:
In an otherwise dry book, you stumble across a phrase that you hadn't read before: First Etherist. What is that? Backing up, you re-read the paragraph. He or she is invoked as an ancient figure, and the author seems to assume that everyone knows who it refers to. Perhaps they did, back in the author's day, but the passing of time must have eroded whatever legacy he or she created. 

You ask your host about the passage, but it becomes clear that he's never read this book before. He mentions a few other libraries you might want to examine - "Nowhere near as good as my own, of course, but they may contain some specialist works that could help you find an answer to that particular question." So be it! You will try to uncover the mystery of the First Etherist.
fields.title: The First Etherist?

fields.description: For whatever reason, this library doesn't seem to include any Kingdom books on ether. Perhaps the owner fears ether, or the Queen's displeasure, or both.
fields.title: Bookless

fields.description:
You find a recent book from the Kingdom. More of a pamphlet than a book, really, but it still sheds some useful light on the topic. 

Etherists are people who have devoted study to manipulation of the ether. All humans can affect the ether to some degree, but most only do so inadvertently. Similarly, anyone can read or hear about ether, but many find it difficult to consciously touch it. Etherists therefore share a mix of natural talent and disciplined learning that results in the ability to perform tasks through the ether at will.  The pamphlet includes brief synopses on some influential contemporary etherists, mostly based at the Lyceum in the Kingdom but several others scattered through the Republic and various Houses.
fields.title: Etherists Explained

fields.description: You pick up a book that looks promising, only to eventually discover that it's a children's book of nonsense. Best not to be seen reading this.
fields.title: Absurdities

fields.description:
The book you find doesn't only include tales indigenous to Lok, but a few tales from lands farther away carried here by sailors. You lose yourself in the stories of enormous flying lizards, of men with four arms, of seas made of glass and waterfalls stuck in time. 

There is no direct mention of ether anywhere, but many of the stories include components that could be partially explained by ether manipulation. Perhaps some of these myths were first created as a way to explain ether to people who could not understand it.
fields.title: Maps and Legends

fields.description: The tome seems written for someone already well-versed in Lyceum culture, and does not pause to explain its various phrases, references, and acronyms. You give up in disgust.
fields.title: Jargon File

fields.description: You encounter a couple of brief mentions of the First Etherist, although the writers never explain his or her significance. There's enough information there to indicate that they predated the Lyceum, though. It looks like the Lyceum has a tradition of honoring the First Etherist, and a few of the teachings the book describes claim to descend in some way from the First Etherist.
fields.title: Etherist History

fields.description: Each book you read seems to refer you to another, until you're lost in a web of secondary sources. There must be actual information available, but where?
fields.title: Looping Footnotes

fields.description:
Considering the enormous impact that the Unity War had on the makeup of Lok, it's surprising that more isn't known of the King's origins. You read about the ascension of Patriarch Sedoron, his feud with House Forcan, the foundation of the Kingdom, and the stunning set of victories that led to his conquest of Lok. 

The book repeats the common claim that Sedoron's victories were assured by his "little army" of etherists, who wielded destructive control over ether to demoralize and conquer his foes. Such an army could not have been created overnight, though. Where did they come from? You learn some tantalizing facts about their backgrounds, but nothing conclusive.
fields.title: Before the King

fields.description: You pass a highly enjoyable if unilluminating hour reading the creative insults a writer from the Lyceum directs towards etherists practicing in the Republic.
fields.title: Personal Attacks

fields.description: One might expect that the etherists of the Kingdom Lyceum form a contingent opposed to foreign etherists. The truth is much more nuanced. The lyceum contains a cacophony of dissenting voices, and the most dire vendettas are between persons highly placed in the lyceum's hierarchy. Similarly, while the lyceum tends to look down upon etherists practicing outside their walls, some lyceum etherists have a great deal of respect for other individuals: Brother Motag of the Republic, the Rawata family of XXX, the fugitive Panreta. The big distinction seems to be one of history: the lyceum has a long tradition and an unbroken history of teaching, while in other places etherists are generally self-taught, live in moderately hostile surroundings, and while they may make an impact they generally leave little legacy behind when they leave.
fields.title: A Warring Tapestry

fields.description: You search through the shelves of multiple libraries without any luck. It must lie elsewhere.
fields.title: Lost in Stacks

fields.description:
At last, you've found the answer: Sonomin was the First Etherist! You read through the entire book in close detail.

Sonomin was the great-great-great grandfather of Sedoron, who would one day become the King of Lok. Sonomin had a natural talent for working with ether, though he was wise enough to make sure that only his most trusted relatives knew of it. At that time, ether was even more feared than today. A commoner accused of practicing ether would be blamed for all sorts of natural misfortunes and lynched. A member of a House wouldn't suffer such a fate, but would lose influence among the family. Sonomin's secrecy allowed him to remain in the line of succession, and he eventually became Patriarch.

Patriarch Sonomin couldn't gain much direct advantage over manipulation of ether, but he foresaw that this feared skill could one day provide a  boon to his House. Therefore, Sonomin started a House school. Officially, it would teach topics like military tactics and cryptography. However, Sonomin quietly hired etherists as well, who shared knowledge amongst themselves and sought to refine their techniques.

After Sonomin's passing, the school gradually evolved into today's lyceum. While the Kingdom has never officially acknowledged Sonomin's talents, his crucial patronage has led to the relatively close ties the Kingdom has with etherists. Their talents directly contributed to Sedoron's rise to supremacy, and they continue to honor Sonomin as the First Etherist. Not the first man to wield ether, but the one who started an unbroken tradition that continues to this day.

In order to prevent anyone else from needing to put in the sort of legwork your own search required, you resolve to write your own book, "Who Was the First Etherist?" It will only attract a specialist audience, but such people will pay fairly well for that sort of thing.
fields.title: The Mystery Solved

fields.description: You lost.
fields.title: You lost

fields.description: You won!
fields.title: You won.

fields.description: The thief defeated you and took your money.
fields.title: You lost.

fields.description: You vanquished the thief.
fields.title: You won.

fields.description: Lost
fields.title: Lost

fields.description: Won
fields.title: Won

fields.description: "Excellent! Here, let me draw you a map of the best way to get there from here... there you go. Please hurry. She hasn't been returning my letters for several months now; she's always been reliable, but I fear the worst has happened!"
fields.title: On to Tandan

fields.description: "Ugh! That's from that asinine Teron, right? I told him that we were through! I've set up quite a successful business for myself out here in Tandan, and he wants me to give it all up to settle for a squalid life, living with him and his parents. Absolutely not!" She sighs. "Well, judging from the look on your face, he didn't bother to tell him that part. Here, I'll pay you for your trouble. If you see him again, please try and get it through his thick skull that he needs to move on and find someone new."
fields.title: Icy Response

fields.description: "Ah, how very nice! Here, let me pick out a shade. This one complements your complexion nicely. And, if you'll allow me, I'll add a buttonhole free of charge. There, you look stunning!"
fields.title: All Dressed Up

fields.description:
She quickly warms to the idea. "Yes, what a nice thought. Here, please take some samples. Walk around and direct people in my direction. I'll pay a referral for each person you send. Remember to smile!"

The time passes quickly and pleasantly, and you earn a few extra coins at the end.
fields.title: Flower Squad

fields.description: She seems a little perplexed at your offer, but agrees to take your money to allow you to handle the flowers. You examine each closely, inhale its fragrance, note the shape of its sepals, and make a few notes. How very interesting!
fields.title: Garden of Delights

fields.description:
"Ah, capital idea! Tell you what - I can draw the elder from memory. You can have the sketch for free, and sell it for what you like. With luck, one day he'll hire me for a proper painting."

You wait for him to finish the sketch, then sell it as suggested. It seems there's profit to be had for a middleman.
fields.title: The Smart Money

fields.description: The artist doesn't initially understand your request, but when you strike a pose with blade in hand, he quickly gets the idea. He works quickly and effectively, transforming your standing body into fixed form on the paper. When he's finished, you're impressed by the work he's done at capturing your position. You are forced to rethink the effectiveness of your default stance.
fields.title: Graceful Form

fields.description: The artist works hard, and you start to grow weary of holding a pose for so long. It proves worthwhile in the end, though, as the resulting portrait is truly stunning. When he tries to hand the finished work to you, you demur, saying that there's insufficient room in your pack. Instead, you ask him to hang it in the nearest tavern, and he gladly accepts.
fields.title: Worth a Thousand Words

fields.description: You listen to the vigorous, stirring song of King Sedoron's pitched battle against House Hansa on the banks of the River Tanalga. You can't help tapping your foot at the heartfelt refrain. Soon the entire tavern joins in, singing heartily along in unison: "UP, swung the axes! DOWN, came the blows! OUT, flew their lifeblood! To the river it flowed!"
fields.title: When the Tanalga Ran Red

fields.description: The bard sings one of the great old love songs, about a doomed love between a Patriarch's daughter and her cook. This song receives a fresh interpretation from each singer, and this one has come up with a few particularly colorful phrases that you commit to memory.
fields.title: The Fair Maid of Caranta

fields.description: This bard knows the tale of Brown Haron, one of Lok's most legendary thieves. He tells the story of how Haron ran ahead of King Sedoron's approaching army, infiltrated House Forcan when it was on its highest guard, and spirited away its treasure under the eyes of the Patriarch. Rogues to this day admire Haron's unique mix of stealth, guile, and dexterity, and seek to emulate his exploits.
fields.title: Forcan's Folly

fields.description: You couldn't quite land any of your throws. The carnival barker encourages you to come back and try your luck again later.
fields.title: Missed Them

fields.description: You manage to knock over one of the pins and win a small prize.
fields.title: A Good Hit

fields.description: You hit one of the pins with such great accuracy that it knocks over all of the others in one blow. The people around you burst into spontaneous applause, and the carnival barker gives you a grand prize as an award.
fields.title: Great Aim!

fields.description: You can barely manage to lift the enormous iron hammer, let alone swing it with enough force to ring the bell. Still, if nothing else, it's a good workout.
fields.title: Thunk

fields.description: Huffing and straining, you manage to lift the hammer, and deliver a powerful blow that rings the gong loudly enough for everyone in the carnival to hear. You take a bow and accept the prize.
fields.title: Gong!

fields.description: Whoops! People around here are paying a little too close attention to their possessions. You back off before attracting too much attention.
fields.title: Tight Pockets

fields.description: With enough coins frequently changing hands, it isn't too hard to intercept a few exchanges without notice. A few bumps, murmured apologies, and you're on your way before they notice what has happened.
fields.title: An Easy Lift

fields.description: You casually amble through the city streets. Without being too obvious about it, you're watching everyone nearby. Whenever you have a moment with all eyes off you, you nonchalantly drop a leaflet to the ground and use your boot to slide it under the nearest door. After an hour you have gotten rid of all of them. You return to the man, but he seems to have moved on.
fields.title: Distributed

fields.description: The captain of the guard seems as befuddled as you about this man, but agrees that it won't do to have potentially dangerous elements wandering the street. He captures him with little complaint, and gives you a small gift as a citizen's finder fee.
fields.title: Captured

fields.description: "You! You're one of THEM! You're in on it! I knew it from the moment I first laid eyes on you! Go on, run back to your masters, tell them that all the contraptions and ether in the world can't protect people from their own destiny! The price must be repaid, and woe to us all when the bill comes due!"
fields.title: Sputtering

fields.description:
"Oh! I... I see. Yes, I can see how that would disturb people. No, I can't stop, but I'll try to... refine my position and express myself at a lower volume. Thank you for bringing this to my attention."

The man wanders off, lost in thought. Townsfolk standing nearby clap you on your shoulders in gratitude. "I thought we'd never get rid of him! Oh, he'll probably come back ranting another day, but at least we have a bit of quiet now."
fields.title: Much Better Now

fields.description: You push hard all day long, alternating between spadework, planting, and tilling. The pay at the end seems measly, but the exercise has helped a good deal.
fields.title: A Hard Day's Work

fields.description: You intercept a few other likely candidates and convince them to join your crew. When you present a complete team to the owner, he hires you on the spot. Everyone works hard for the day, and happily receives a cut of pay at the end. Nobody begrudges your share, even if you didn't physically work nearly as hard.
fields.title: Overseer

fields.description: They're voracious creatures, but not terribly skilled at covering their tracks. You point out their warren to the owner, who pays you a fee and promises he'll take care of the rest.
fields.title: Got Them!

fields.description: Unfortunately, you fail to win the roll. You congratulate your competitors on a fine showing.
fields.title: Unfavorable Fortune

fields.description: A fine roll! You sweep up your winnings and accept the kudos from your competitors.
fields.title: Raking It In

fields.description: Your competitors spot you trying to pull a move! You need to pay out a little more to calm them down and avoid serious trouble.
fields.title: A Clumsy Grab

fields.description: You wait until the other players' attentions wander before making your "roll." It comes out to your advantage, of course. You pocket the winnings and try to ignore the baleful gazes in your direction.
fields.title: Smooth Tilt

fields.description:
The cartel operates all over the city, but the most important merchants tend to congregate on the western side near the port. One of the cartel's representatives agrees to talk with you, and offers some advice.

"You'll find that we're a fairly open-minded group. We don't much care who you are or where you came from: so long as you're bringing trade through Risapo, you're helping us and our city. Do it for long enough, and we'll officially recognize you as part of the cartel."

When you ask for some guidance to get started, she shrugs. "Risapo has access to some exotic trade goods from the islands, and tends to be in need of simple raw materials. Keep your eye open for business opportunities here and when you travel abroad. Remember, speaking with the right person can earn many more royals than simply visiting any nearby market."
fields.title: Deeds and Words

fields.description: The merchant-captain impresses you with the quality of her cargo, and you agree to pay 10 royals a piece for them. Hopefully you can find someone willing to pay at least that much to buy.
fields.title: Five Carvings

fields.description: You spot a few minor blemishes on a few of the carvings, which shouldn't matter much to the ultimate buyer but do give you the ability to argue down the price.
fields.title: Five Carvings - At a Discount

fields.description: Some local merchants like the idea of an attention-grabbing foreign carving, and negotiate a decent price for a set of them.
fields.title: A Fair Price

fields.description: You find that some local children love the prospect of journeying to foreign lands, and are willing to scrounge up a great deal of coin for a tangible symbol of their destination.
fields.title: A Good Price

fields.description: The farmer has many potential buyers for his wheat, and doesn't see the advantage in giving you a discount. Still, you are able to agree on a reasonable price.
fields.title: Wheat Alone

fields.description: The farmer agrees to double your supply for the existing cost, so long as you accept delivery from the end of the harvest. Since you plan to sell it on, you cheerfully agree.
fields.title: Bumper Crop

fields.description: It looks like most millers have already locked in agreements for a full supply of grain. You agree to sell your own scrip for the going rate.
fields.title: Flooded Market

fields.description: You find some farmers in the market and convince them to purchase your wheat script to use as animal feed. After a handshake, the scrip and the royals are exchanged.
fields.title: A Going Concern

fields.description: The ferrywoman accepts your coins. You are her only passenger today, and she chats about Hansa on the ride over. With the natural border of Tanalga to the west and the generally peaceful Republic to the east, Hansa has mostly avoided the periodic wars that plague the other Houses. She lets you know where the other ferries operate from should you need to cross back to Hansa in the future, and wishes you good fortune when you arrive on the far side.
fields.title: Hansa

fields.description: You buy a large set of swords, ignoring the nagging feeling that you may have overpaid.
fields.title: Armful of Copper

fields.description: Copper is falling out of fashion for swords, and you convince the smith to give you a break on the price.
fields.title: Discount Blades

fields.description: The quartermaster takes the swords off your hands, though for no more royals than you'd have earned at the market. Still, he will be a valuable contact to cultivate.
fields.title: Provisioned

fields.description: The quartermaster has recently had a bad experience with another vendor, and is eager to develop alternate suppliers. He pays you well for your swords.
fields.title: The Right Price

fields.description:
You don't need to search at all - the merchants find you. Clapping you on your back, they whisk you off to a banquet hall where several dozen other traders have already gathered.

A sumptuous feast is laid out, including roasted game hens with blackberry sauce, bowls of leek-and-potato soup, bacon-wrapped red snapper, baked butternut squash, black bread with honey-flavored butter, mangoes from the islands, and a bewildering assortment of pies: blueberry pies, strawberry pies, soured-cream-and-apple pies, sweet potato pies, and lemon tarts. 

When the last dishes have been cleared away, one of the members rises to introduce you. "#TITLE_NAME# has only been in our fair city for a short time, but already #HE_SHE# has made quite an impression on us. #HE_SHE_CAP# has shown tenacity in finding good deals, skill at bargaining for the best prices, and loyalty in bringing the benefits of trade back to Risapo. I hereby propose that we accept #TITLE_NAME# as a member in good standing to the Risapo cartel!"

Shouts of general acclaim confirm your appointment. You receive hearty handshakes and offerings of future support in your commercial endeavors.
fields.title: Inducted

fields.description: This tapestry looks quite impressive, and you happily hand over a hundred royals for it.
fields.title: Royal Warp

fields.description: You find an up-and-coming textile artist who is happy to part with her work at a lower price, hoping for more exposure in return.
fields.title: Weft Royals

fields.description: A local collector agrees to purchase the tapestry for a fair price.
fields.title: Parting

fields.description: While you are demonstrating your wares, a passer-by falls in love with the tapestry and buys it on the spot, for a quite handsome sum of royals.
fields.title: Enthusiast

fields.description:
An elderly tavern patron recalls that sigil belonging to the late Pater Velkin. You encourage some friends to keep their eyes open when they travel through Velkin's old lands, and eventually one of them returns with the item. 

The sign is smaller than the adventurer described, but he enthusiastically accepts it. "I can't wait for the day I can show this to my boy, and tell him about the first heroic deed done by his father! Come back tomorrow, and I'll have another job for you."
fields.title: Team Effort

fields.description:
After reading through old geographic surveys, you deduce that the fox sign must have been erected by Pater Velkin, whose family has used that sigil for generations. You learn which roads existed back then and travel them slowly, eventually spotting the sign in question. 

The sign is smaller than the adventurer described, but he enthusiastically accepts it. "I can't wait for the day I can show this to my boy, and tell him about the first heroic deed done by his father! Come back tomorrow, and I'll have another job for you."
fields.title: Tracking the Sign

fields.description: A merchant trader has seen someone matching that description. The thief kept his word in that he became a bard; however, rather than singing the adventurer's praises, he's been maligning the man for the last decade, telling tale after tale of the adventurer's cruelty, deceitfulness, and greed. Your client will not enjoy hearing this. It's not a story for his children to hear.
fields.title: A Different Tune

fields.description: You find the promised tale in a collection of local songs. The thief kept his word in that he became a bard; however, rather than singing the adventurer's praises, he maligns the man, telling a tale of the adventurer's cruelty, deceitfulness, and greed. Your client will not enjoy hearing this. It's not a story for his children to hear.
fields.title: Libel

fields.description: You track the man down to a tavern in a small village. The thief kept his word in that he became a bard; however, rather than singing the adventurer's praises, he's telling a tale of the adventurer's cruelty, deceitfulness, and greed. Your client will not enjoy hearing this. It's not a story for his children to hear.
fields.title: Another Tune

fields.description: The bard's eyes soften when you explain your task. "No kidding, he's starting a family? That's wonderful! Honestly, I never thought that my words would hurt him so. A bard needs to tell impressive tales to get ahead, and a kind man sparing my life does not sound exciting. I owe everything to him, though, so I'll gladly make it up to him: I'll sing his praises twice as loudly as I ever slandered him."
fields.title: A New Man

fields.description: Some scary men accept your coins. It's a little disturbing how little a life can be worth. Their leader returns the next day and silently gives you a nod. The deed is done, and the adventurer's legacy is his own once more.
fields.title: The Deed is Done

fields.description: You confront the bard as he exits the tavern. He initially acts belligerently, but after a few blows he quickly changes his tune. You make it abundantly clear that a single additional lie will result in a more fatal return visit. He acquiesces so pitifully that you have no doubt the adventurer's legacy will be secure.
fields.title: The Bruise of Truth

fields.description: As you might expect, he puts up a vicious and dirty fight, but your fury helps carry the day. The bard will trouble the retiring adventurer no more.
fields.title: Silenced

fields.description: "Done! She will serve you well, I have no doubt. Thank you again for all your help!"
fields.title: A Fine Steed

fields.description: "Done! Spend it well - I know that adventurers like us can always use extra coin. Thank you again for your help!"
fields.title: Royal Thanks

fields.description: "Done! As you can see by the fact I'm still alive, this is a very good set of armor. May it serve you just as well!"
fields.title: Safer

fields.description: She won't say one word to you! How discouraging. Perhaps the next day will find her in a better mood.
fields.title: Steely Gaze

fields.description: "You seem like a nice enough sort. I need to keep a low profile because I'm... well, I'm an etherist. Most people fear us, especially in small towns like this where they've only heard the legends of our supposed awful deeds. I don't want to bother anyone, though. I just want to keep to myself and conduct my experiments. Please help me keep this a secret."
fields.title: A Confession

fields.description: You try to move silently, but she recognizes your presence, and glares at you until you slink away. You may have more luck next time.
fields.title: Noticed

fields.description:
You slip into the small cottage when she leaves and rifle through her copious documents. Aha! She seems to be an etherist, a woman who practices manipulation of the ether to affect the world around her. She has been driven out of several other villages before this one. It looks like she's seeking to establish a study or laboratory of some sort.

You commit the most important information to memory and then leave, being sure that no trace is left behind.
fields.title: Mystery Revealed

fields.description: You find a few references that seem like they could refer to this woman, but they are confused and contradictory. You'll need to keep looking.
fields.title: Puzzling Evidence

fields.description: This woman is a published author! She is an etherist, a person who specializes in the manipulation of ether to affect the physical world. Etherists aren't very popular, particularly outside of major cities, so she's been moving around lately. Her book expresses a longing to establish some sort of study or laboratory. Could that be what she's doing here?
fields.title: A Woman of Note

fields.description:
You whip up an angry mob in record time. Waving torches and farm implements, they arrive at her cottage at night and force her to flee, shrieking, from the village.

The matron finds you among the ebullient crowd. "I'm so glad you could take care of that for me! Here, please take this as a little reward. With the cottage open now, I think I'll invite my niece in to take over it. She's an etherist as well, but do keep that quiet for me, hmmm?"
fields.title: Fie! Fie!

fields.description:
Much to the etherist's surprise, the town doesn't turn against her. In fact, many young children are brave enough to ask her questions about the ether. After she shows them a few simple tricks, they demand to be taught more.

Before long, the etherist starts openly running a school for instruction in the Ether. Such institutions rarely last long, at least outside of the Kingdom, but the villagers seem to appreciate it. The etherist even gives you a few private lessons as thanks for not turning against her.
fields.title: The New School

fields.description: The etherist appreciates your discretion. "I hope to live here for many more years, and will rely on the kindness of people like you to keep safe. Please stop by if you ever feel like chatting, and don't share my secret with the matron."
fields.title: Incognito

fields.description:
You whip up an angry mob in record time. Waving torches and farm implements, they arrive at her cottage at night and force her to flee, shrieking, from the village.

The matron finds you among the ebullient crowd. "I'm so glad you could take care of that for me! Here, please take this as a little reward. With the cottage open now, I think I'll invite my niece in to take over it. She's an etherist as well, but do keep that quiet for me, hmmm?"
fields.title: Fie! Fie!

fields.description:
Much to the etherist's surprise, the town doesn't turn against her. In fact, many young children are brave enough to ask her questions about the ether. After she shows them a few simple tricks, they demand to be taught more.

Before long, the etherist starts openly running a school for instruction in the Ether. Such institutions rarely last long, at least outside of the Kingdom, but the villagers seem to appreciate it. The etherist even gives you a few private lessons as thanks for not turning against her.
fields.title: The New School

fields.description: She enthusiastically receives your donation. "This is wonderful! I'll be able to construct cages and collect animals for my experiments!" You don't inquire into the nature of those experiments. She gives you a few introductory ether lessons in compensation.
fields.title: Laboratory Growing

fields.description: Everything was going so well! But then you pulled a muscle and had to limp back to your place of rest.
fields.title: Ouch!

fields.description: You run and jump around the yard for close to an hour. You feel exhausted by the end, but it's a good sort of exhaustion. Your body is getting more firmly under your control again.
fields.title: Stronger

fields.description:
"Oh... of course, #TITLE_NAME#! We wouldn't dream of neglecting you!"

You pass the rest of the day surrounded by the tender ministrations of the Mercy Home staff. Their treatments help you feel better, and the attention doesn't hurt either.
fields.title: Circle of Admirers

fields.description: The young aide accepts your offering with gratitude. He hovers around you for the rest of the day, preferring a regular supply of unguents and poultices. You feel much refreshed.
fields.title: Much Better

fields.description: Many other walking wounded are clamoring for treatment. You wait your turn and eventually receive some fresh bandages, herbs, and unguents. You feel better after applying them to your wounds.
fields.title: Help at the End

fields.description:
The courier whisks you through a dizzying series of hallways, up and down several flights of stairs, eventually depositing you before Pell, one of the heirs to House Gol.

Pell greets you courteously before broaching his request. "My brother Dall has been away with the army for some time now, but still commands loyalty among many serving here in the Great House. I wish to discover who he is communicating with, and eventually influence his allies to support me instead. I will need someone with great subtlety to pull this off, and I believe that #MAN_WOMAN# is you, #TITLE_NAME#."

Pell offers you some more wine. "My brother's personal quarters are rarely visited these days. Please make your way there without being seen and... borrow some clothes from him. His cloak and hood in particular, anything with his seal. We're going to make an actor out of you, #TITLE_NAME#, and if you play your role well, you could pick the next Patriarch of House Gol."
fields.title: An Impersonator in Training

fields.description: A small but furious man spots you at the end of the hall and sprints in your direction. "What are you doing here?! Guards! Guards!" You retreat under a volley of violent blows.
fields.title: Belligerent Guard

fields.description: You silently creep through the halls in the black of night, making it as far as Dall's outer quarters. These rooms are relatively sparse, but you see a hood that seems to belong to Dall. You snatch it, along with a few loose coins lying on the nearest table in the foyer.
fields.title: Getting a Hood

fields.description: You reach Dall's bedroom, but while you are searching his wardrobe, a servant enters his room. He lets out a powerful shriek. You dive for the window, and suffer grievous scrapes as you tumble down to the ground.
fields.title: Surprised in the Act

fields.description: You move like a ghost through the halls, through Dall's rooms, into the very heart of his suite. His wardrobe is unlocked, and a quick rummage through it reveals a single cloak, fresh from the tailor. It has exquisite stitching, proudly emblazoned with Dall's sigil: a naked blade, red on black. You grab the cloak and a few royals in the bedroom, and quickly leave before the servants arrive to make their rounds.
fields.title: Cloaked in Trickery

fields.description: Your little excursion seems to be going well, until you run into a patrol of soldiers freshly returned from the Forcan front. The captain blanches. "Who… who are you, and why are you wearing Dall's clothes?" Caught! You flee before they can apprehend you. This disguise is now useless; you'll need to find another to conceal yourself in.
fields.title: An Inquisitive Soldier

fields.description: You stroll slowly and grandly around the better parts of Gamanar, every fiber of your essence oozing privilege. None of the commoners dare meet your eyes. It's a little trickier when you encounter some soldiers, but when one of them opens their mouth, a withering gaze from you immediately silences her. Excellent. You're getting the hang of playing this role.
fields.title: A Noble Impersonation

fields.description: You feel eyes pricking the back of your neck with every step you take. The captain of the guard confronts you coldly in the courtyard. "I hope this is just a particularly ill-thought joke," she says. You pass a disagreeable night in the dungeon.
fields.title: Roughed Up

fields.description: You arrogantly stride around the Great House. You grow so bold as to grunt out an occasional order, and see that they are swiftly obeyed. Your performance seems to be beyond reproach.
fields.title: A Confident Performance

fields.description: Before you even reach Dall's briefing room you sense that your cover has been blown. Too many startled looks, too many whispered orders. You create a disturbance and slip away, leaving your disguise behind to avoid detection.
fields.title: Exposed

fields.description:
Dall's councilors accept your explanation about your voice and why you must hide your face. So eager are they to curry favor with the future heir of House Gol, they will excuse any perceived weakness of yours.

You listen patiently to their reports. Dall has been traveling between military outposts, speaking personally with the commanders and winning them to his cause. You silently record the names of his latest recruits.

When the advisors ask if you have any orders, you shake your head. Not yet. But soon.
fields.title: Inner Circle

fields.description:
You rush to Pell's bedchambers and shake him awake. "Whu... how did you get in here?" he exclaims; then upon seeing you he grins. "Oh, of course it was you, #NAME#. Who else could get past my guards?"

After listening to your warning, Pell springs into action, immediately notifying all of the Great House's administrators, agents, and liaisons. The merchants hear of the disorder and raise a great hue and cry, until the entire city is roused up. Dall has no option but to disavow any responsibility for the troop movements. The soldiers slink back to their posts and their commanders are thrown in prison.

Pell thanks you profusely. "All of House Gol is in your debt, #TITLE_NAME#. My brother and I must resolve our differences through rational argument, not blades. Please accept this token of my appreciation for your great service."
fields.title: A Crisis Averted

fields.description:
You warn Dall's messenger that Pell has learned about all of his movements so far. Without betraying your own involvement, you tell him that someone has been masquerading as Dall, and to consider all recent messages compromised.

The agent shakes his head sadly. "We thought that Dall would pull this off, but it now seems like he would just be marching into a trap. Gamanar is such a den of snakes, filled with liars and sneaks! No wonder Dall prefers to spend all his time out in the country, where men are honest and say what they mean. Still, we thank you for your assistance. We'll ensure that Pell can't spy on us any more."
fields.title: Double Agent

fields.description:
"Ah, good to see you, #TITLE_NAME#. Please do have a seat. Care for a glass of wine?

"Now, to business. The Cartel leadership has decided to tie our economy more closely with that of the Kingdom. They're natural trading partners of ours: we share a common border, and they control valuable sea routes with access to exotic goods; in exchange, we specialize in the high-quality craftsmanship that their cities so crave.

"Unfortunately, due to a lengthy history of conflict, our states share a reluctance in dealing with one another. We hope that will change, but in the meantime, we can improve the likelihood of comprehensive trade with the Kingdom by diminishing the amount of trade with Naper, our neighbor to the north.

"For too long, merchants from Tandan and Naper have dealt with one another simply out of habit. I want you to help expose that weakness. Naper and Hansa have little contact, and an enterprising #MAN_WOMAN# like yourself could greatly profit by increasing their connections. This, in turn, will put pressure on Tandan to seek a new trading partner to the south.

"To be blunt, I'm asking you to ignore Tandan for now. Convince Naper that they should be trading with Hansa. Hopefully the rest will fall into place, and we will compensate you well for your actions."
fields.title: Cold Trade War

fields.description: Lost
fields.title: Lost

fields.description: Won
fields.title: Won

fields.description: Lost
fields.title: Lost

fields.description: Won
fields.title: Won

fields.description: Lost
fields.title: Lost

fields.description: Won
fields.title: Won

fields.description:
The missing child is none other than Gell, the son of Dell and a possible future Patriarch of Gol! When you offer to help, Gol soldiers march you directly into the unsmiling presence of Dell. He looks to have been in the countryside for weeks or months, and is grimly discussing matters with some unhappy hunters.

Dell summarizes the facts, scant though they are. "Gell recently turned ten, and asked if he could leave Gamanar to travel with me. I was happy to remove him from that viper's nest, and his mother agreed. After two nights here he vanished from his tent. A note said that he had left to go home, but it was written in another hand. Someone must have snatched him away, and wanted to buy time to make their escape."

He shows you a map of the area. "We have searched the surroundings thoroughly but found no evidence of my son. Military matters require my presence elsewhere. I will leave a small company of soldiers in this camp to watch you and reward any progress you make. I'm trusting you to fulfill your duty. Do this, and you will earn Gol's great gratitude."
fields.title: A Kidnapping

fields.description: The activity of dozens of soldiers have obscured much information that might have been useful. Today's searchings reveal nothing useful.
fields.title: Cleaned Up

fields.description: You turn up a few signs that look like they may have been made by a much smaller person than the soldiers occupying the camp. That's most likely evidence of Gell's presence. You'll need to look further to find anything more useful, but you have a better idea now of what Gell's trail looks like.
fields.title: Faint Signs

fields.description: You spy what might be the tracks of a child, but they're swallowed up by more recent markings from soldiers' boots. There's nothing useful here.
fields.title: Muddled Paths

fields.description: You see some signs of passage. Small tracks, probably Gell's. Those of another man. They seem to be going in the same direction. You study them carefully.
fields.title: Hasty Exit

fields.description: Several streams run through the area, which may have interrupted Gell's trail. You sense that this is the right area, but can't find anything tangible linking to him.
fields.title: Passing Through

fields.description: There! In the mud - bootprints that match those you saw at camp. The heir and the captor must be nearby.
fields.title: Footprints

fields.description: Someone has spent a night here recently, but you can't tell whether it was Gell or not. Regardless, whoever was here must have left several days ago. Time to keep searching.
fields.title: Bare Cavern

fields.description: The cave is empty now, but your attention is immediately drawn to a firepit. Your quarry was here several days ago. Sifting through the ash, you pull out some intact greenwood from the fire. It appears to have been collected close by. You should be able to find where they've gone by looking for recently hacked tree limbs.
fields.title: Cavernous

fields.description: The man spots you and reacts quickly: he grabs the lad, throws him over his shoulder, and takes off running. He runs up and over a hill, and by the time you reach the crest, he has vanished from view.
fields.title: Gone Instantly

fields.description: The man spots you and reacts quickly: he grabs the lad, throws him over his shoulder, and takes off running. You keep pace, anticipating where the terrain will force him to run, and quickly reading his tracks when he cuts through the woods. You eventually lose him after ten minutes' pursuit, but feel confident that you've chased him from whatever destination he was trying to reach.
