He's on more uncertain ground now, and your next encounter should prove more successful.
fields.title: A Long Chase

fields.description:
The tracks lead you to a clearing. You lurk in the shade of the trees and watch as a single man converses with several companions on horseback. The man wears a rough brown leather coat and his hair is cut short in the Forcan style. The riders bear no identifying marks, but seem out of place here in Gol.

The exchange concludes amiably and one of the riders tosses a bag of provisions to the man. You need to hide when the riders approach your position, and by the time you emerge the clearing is empty.
fields.title: The Villain

fields.description:
You find Gell in a cave, manacled to a rock. He seems scared and hungry, but otherwise uninjured. Gell relaxes visibly when you tell him you were sent by his father. "I knew he would not abandon me to that man. Please release me, and let us find the nearest patrol."

After breaking the lock, you and Gell search the cave for any evidence. Gell says that his captor was taciturn, rarely speaking but frequently writing. A few scraps of paper are all you can find, and Gell takes them in hand before you leave the cave.

You return to the camp where you had met Dall. The soldiers cheer at the sight of Gell. The sergeant shakes your hand solemnly. "This will take an enormous weight off of Dall's mind. Kaman knows he's had enough to worry about with all the strife within and without our House. We'll ride to him immediately, but you should visit him at your leisure. I'm sure he'll want to thank you personally."
fields.title: Rescued!

fields.description:
Dall seems like a stern man, so you are caught unprepared when he embraces you in a giant hug. "I cannot thank you enough for rescuing Gell. He is my only son so far, and losing my line would have meant a difficult ascension to the Patriarchy."

When you ask him who was behind the kidnapping, his smile vanishes. "I wish I knew. My thoughts immediately turn to my brother Pell, who sits in Gamanar like a spider and weaves his webs of deception throughout our House. He would benefit most from Gell's death. That said, why bother kidnapping him instead of simply killing him? Much as I hate to admit it, Pell is probably innocent of this one crime."

Dall gestures toward a map. "The real culprit is probably here: one of House Gol's enemies. They know I command our armies, and were hoping to gain some leverage over me. Perhaps they were waiting for a crucial moment to strike. The letters you and Gell found in the cave were written in code, but addressed to cities in Forcan. Their amassing armies lead me to believe that they were responsible for this insult."

He hands you a purse of royals and clasps you once more. "House Gol is a complex place. Often too complex. A need a loyal #MAN_WOMAN# like yourself, #TITLE_NAME#, and I hope I can count on you in my - in my House's - hour of greatest need."
fields.title: Wheels Within Wheels

fields.description:
You charm your way up the ladder of rank until you secure a private meeting with Pell. Nearly private, at least; couriers regularly slip in to drop off a note or whisper in his ear.

"You seem to have lived an impressive life, #TITLE_NAME#. Please allow me to tell you a little of my own. I was born one year after my brother Dall. By tradition of the House, he should ascend to the seat of the Patriarch after our father's death. However, Dall has shown little desire in governance. He would much rather play at being a soldier! He delights in ordering our armies around, and recklessly enters battle at every opportunity."

Pell shakes his head in disgust. "Oh, don't misunderstand, he's a fine general, but would make an awful Patriarch. Gol is a small House, and the only reason we have survived this long is thanks to the good alliances we have made with the Republic and friendly Patriarchs from other Houses. Dall wants the glory of fighting a war, but if he gets his chance, it will mean the end of us all."

When you ask what chance Pell has of dislodging his brother, he shrugs. "Better than you might think. Custom says that the eldest inherits, but it's only custom, not law. In the past, Gol has passed over men who were childless or simpletons and elevated more qualified rulers instead. While Dall is beloved by the army and many commoners, the people who matter - those in the Great House who actually administer this House - recognize that I would be a far wiser choice."

Another courier arrives, and Pell motions for him to stay. "Resan, please meet #TITLE_NAME#. #HE_SHE_CAPITAL# will be speaking with leaders in the Great House about the line of succession. Resan will see that you're compensated for your successful efforts to sway any reluctant supporters to my cause."
fields.title: Swaying the Great House

fields.description: A farmer is willing to part with his sugar. His mood sours when you mention that you plan on selling it to Naper. "Hmph, I don't see why you would. Tandan's always been more than happy to buy whatever we can produce. If they don't buy it from us, where will they get their sugar from?"
fields.title: Sickly Stuff

fields.description: The farmer you speak with is curious about your intentions. "So, you're a member of the Risapo Cartel, but you're selling sugar north? Interesting. I suppose that means the smart money's moving up there? I may need to start looking at that market myself!"
fields.title: Sweet Deal

fields.description: The grocer seems somewhat perplexed at the recent popularity of sugarcane, but is willing to stock more to meet the growing demand.
fields.title: Cautious Buyer

fields.description: You find a grocer who happily purchases several scrips promising future delivery of sugar. He asks you several questions about your agricultural contacts in Hansa, and seems to be contemplating more regular purchases.
fields.title: Enthusiastic Buyer

fields.description: These men and women are experts at hiding information behind an impenetrable wall of paper. You are shunted from one office to another without finding anyone who will admit to actual responsibility for anything. You'll need to increase your charm to make headway here.
fields.title: Shuffled Away

fields.description: You focus your attentions on one particular office within the Great House. They welcome an interruption from their tasks, and listen attentively as you describe the benefits of Pell's reasonable, level-headed leadership. They ask perceptive questions like you would expect from someone close to the pulse of governance, and your answers seem to please them. One office down, several left to go!
fields.title: Duly Noted

fields.description: Diplomats truly are the masters of speaking without making any commitments. The men you find listen respectfully to what you say, but reveal nothing of their own intentions. Perhaps they require more convincing, or perhaps they are simply concealing their preferences.
fields.title: Evasive Maneuvers

fields.description: The ambassador you speak with has clearly given a great deal of thought to the Dall/Pell question. He listens to your words, and gives some guarded indications that he prefers Pell's more subtle, inclusive style over Dall's overt and independent actions. You can probably count on this diplomat's support.
fields.title: A Diplomatic Response

fields.description: The tax collector doesn't appear to particularly favor Dall, but doesn't appreciate your arguments against him either. You're left uncomfortably aware of your presence as an outsider, perceived as interfering with Gol's own affairs.
fields.title: Backfire

fields.description: The tax collector seems to have held her own misgivings about Dall: the loss of customs duties if war closes the border with Forcan; interruptions in tax collection as commoners are forced from their lands and conscripted into service; a decrease in excise taxes as production of luxury goods ceases. A successful war can be profitable, but a lost war can bankrupt an entire House, and she shares her colleagues' worries about how Gol might perform in a war.
fields.title: Come Around

fields.description: Neither brother seems to be very popular among this crowd. Cousins remember Dall as a violent and pushy child, and Pell as an obnoxious tattle-tale. You'll need to convince them to look past his prior behavior and see the man he is today.
fields.title: Rivalry

fields.description: You remind the cousin of Pell's generosity to the family, the time he's spent visiting with relatives in the Great House, his tendency to include as many people as possible in any scheme. The cousin starts to imagine greater status in a Pell administration. You've likely won him over.
fields.title: Popularity Contest

fields.description: Dall's combatative stance on Forcan has raised some concerns in the foreign office, but that is tempered by his embrace of closer ties with the Republic. Today, opinion seems to be trending towards seeing Dall as a blunt but effective negotiator.
fields.title: Won't Stick

fields.description: Dall has been agitating for a stronger military alliance with the Republic, a move that would concern neighboring Houses and seems likely to spark an endless war with Forcan. You argue persuasively that the prospect of war is harsh enough to risk upsetting standard procedures and favoring his brother Pell instead.
fields.title: Wild Card

fields.description:
Gol's archivist ordinarily plays a purely historical role, but in the matter of succession, he proves very important: he enters the name of the heir in the Book of Gol. For many years, that name has been Dall. Thanks to your encouragement and build-up of support, he adds another name beside it: Pell. Now either brother can legally succeed their father.

Pell turns enthusiastic at the news. "I knew you could do it! All the barriers are cleared from me now. When the time is right, I can take the seat of the Patriarch and unite Gol behind me. We'll embark on a reign of peace, comity, and prosperity. You will always be welcome here in Gol, #TITLE_NAME#."
fields.title: A New Name

fields.description:
The increasing groundswell of support for Pell has reached a peak, but at the last moment you refrain from organizing that support into concrete change. Inertia returns, and while most of the players in Gamanar look more fondly upon Pell, Dall remains the sole legitimate heir.

Pell predictably turns furious, and refuses to speak with you for days. However, Dall hears word of your crucial change of heart, and sends you a note along with a reward. "I can forgive any #MAN_WOMAN# willing to support me. I hope that you will now prove loyal. Please accept this gift and the thanks of the rightful heir to House Gol."
fields.title: More Dall

fields.description: The Risapo merchants' long ties with Naper is providing difficult to overcome. You describe their high costs, the low quality of their goods, and the unreliability of their supply. The traders listening to you simply shrug and assert their own good experiences.
fields.title: Bad Business

fields.description: Merchants love hearing about weakness, and everyone you speak with eagerly listens to your description of the woes one faces when dealing with a Naper trader. You tell horror stories about late shipments, fluctuating prices, delayed payments. At the end, you murmur almost offhandedly, "Now, the Kingdom... THOSE people know how to treat us well!"
fields.title: The Down Side

fields.description: The farmer offloads a fair amount of price, but doesn't seem very motivated to cut you a break on product destined for Hansa.
fields.title: Slim Yield

fields.description: You meet with a former supplier who remembers your previous purchases. She greets you warmly, and expresses interest when you mention that you're opening up a new trade route with Hansa. You walk away with some attractively-priced scripts for wheat delivery.
fields.title: Handshake Deal

fields.description: You locate a woman willing to acquire your wheat scrips, although she insists on deducting the cost of transport from your fee. Still, she seems open to the prospect of more trade, and may be a contact worth cultivating.
fields.title: Mean Miller

fields.description: You find a mill located directly on the eastern banks of the Tanalga. It operates via a water-driven wheel, an ingenious design created in the Kingdom and gradually spreading throughout the realm. She cheerfully agrees to acquire enough wheat to keep her in operation for another week.
fields.title: Whirring Spokes

fields.description:
You describe in detail the contacts you've made, the trades you've executed, the rumors you've spread, the palms you've greased. The other members of the cartel periodically interject a "Hmm!" or a "Well done!" The entire body erupts in applause when you finish.

The cartel leader affixes a gold pin to your lapel. "We've been happy to call you a member of the Cartel, but today you are truly one of the best of us. Thanks to your efforts, the long and slow process of engaging with the Kingdom has been greatly accelerated. Our people are hungry for sugar, and the Kingdom islands can supply them. Our people are hungry for grain, and the Kingdom lands can offer more. Our craftsmen wish to sell their goods, and I am sure they will find eager buyers to the south. What would have taken years may now take place in months, and everyone will benefit."

The cartel drinks to your health. You are now considered a member in the finest of standings.
fields.title: A New Partner

fields.description:
A sign hung on the massive door reads "Thieves Wanted, Inquire Within." Intrigued, you enter and ask to speak with the person in charge.

He quickly fills you in. "We can't afford any mistakes - every thief in Gol and beyond will hear about this exhibit, and the best will be vying among each other to become the first to break in and steal the jewels. I need to find someone who can test our defenses and help us find our weaknesses. You'll be well compensated for any openings you find. Once we're all satisfied that the place is fully secure, we'll be able to actually bring in the artifacts and open the display."
fields.title: White Hat

fields.description: It looks like they're already prepared for you. The window is secure in its frame, and any shattering of the glass would bring guards running.
fields.title: Shut Tight

fields.description: Nearby trees allow you to climb up to the second story of the mint, where a narrow ledge permits one to carefully move along the wall. You find a small window that could be knocked from its frame without too much noise. It would be difficult to pull off, but possible for someone of your talents. The guards will be happy to hear that you've found a weakness, and should be able to plug it with some sturdy iron bars set inside the window to prevent movement through.
fields.title: Where There's a Will…

fields.description: You labor over the lock for quite a while, but the small size of the keyhole and its awkward placement make it very difficult to crack. Eventually you declare defeat. That's unfortunate for you, since you won't get paid for today, but bodes well for the event's security.
fields.title: Tight as a Drum

fields.description: You work the lock for over an hour before you finally ease it open. That probably means it's secure enough to foil intruders, but does underscore the importance of ensuring that thieves can't make it this far. The watchmen are quite impressed by your efforts and gladly pay your fee.
fields.title: Flip Open

fields.description: You're a little too eager when grabbing the keys. The guard's reflexes kick in and he knocks you to the ground with a savage blow. It's fortunate that they recognize you, otherwise you would be spending the night in jail.
fields.title: Struck Down

fields.description: You manage to snatch the keys while the guard's back is turned without him ever noticing. After verifying that the keys do actually open all the interior doors, you hand them in to the head watchman. He pays your reward and promises to reprimand the guard.
fields.title: Light Fingers

fields.description: You painstakingly wire up a pressure plate, several sets of spikes, a falling log, and some loose rubble… only to have it set off prematurely when a large guard stomps by. Curses!
fields.title: Falls Apart

fields.description: Since a thief would almost certainly come at night, you take advantage of the reduced visibility to include some larger and deadlier components in your trap. A tripwire will set the whole thing off, and in addition to damaging the intruder, it will also release some suspended debris that will prevent them from continuing along this passage. You warn the watchmen to stay clear of this area if they wish to keep in good health.
fields.title: A Better Trap

fields.description: You experiment with false bottoms, concealed hinges, inclined planes. It's an intriguing idea, but you can't make everything connect together properly in this small space. You eventually give up. Perhaps one of the larger cases will prove easier to manage.
fields.title: Complex Mess

fields.description: You build a tiny yet elaborate mechanism that should send any thief into a futile rage. When the case opens, a virtually invisible wire will lift the felt bottom of the case. This will open a hole underneath the artifact, allowing it to fall through the bottom of the case, and into the gigantic stone urn it's attached to. The thief would need to either smash apart the urn, or lift its enormous weight and roll it out of the museum. Either way, they would certainly be noticed by the guards. You accept your fee for this case, and offer to similarly enhance security on the others as well.
fields.title: A Good Trick

fields.description:
You patrol the perimeter, looking up at all the windows and making sure that the trees have been cut back far enough. You interview the guards and ensure that they know their patrols. You check on the various traps you've set up. You institute a new password system that should foil any impostors.

The big day is a smashing success. Highly placed members of the Gol family make an appearance, and the cream of Gamanar society parades through the halls, gasping in loud astonishment at the beauty of Gol's treasure. You lurk in the shadows, watching everyone who passes through, and signaling quietly to the guards whenever someone seems to be paying a bit too much attention to the surroundings.

As you suspected, that night after the doors are locked is when the thief makes his move. Thieves, rather. Someone from Green Haron's gang in Ettan manages to scale the roof and enters through the attic, but is caught by an observant watchman. A trio of sisters from the Republic cajole their way into the entrance and knock out the first line of defense, but are still fiddling with your locks when a wave of reinforcements arrive. And you manage to personally apprehend the drunk son of Pell who seems to be stealing his own jewels in some sort of dare.

When morning comes and the gems are all still in place, you accept the sizable reward and heartfelt thanks of House Gol. Who knew that honesty could pay so well?
fields.title: A Thin Blue Line

fields.description:
All of the bustle taking place around the museum means many eyes watching, but also plenty of distractions. You've gotten to know the guards' routines and blind spots, so you can easily slip into places when nobody is looking.

The secret is to get the gems before they even enter their secured display cases. You have some convincing replicas created that look like the actual crown and scepter, down to the colors of each inlaid jewel. When you carefully "inspect" the artifacts upon delivery, you are sizing up the opportunity to swap them out for your own. A distraction conveniently arises when you "accidentally" direct the procession down one of your booby-trapped corridors. Amongst the noise, cursing, and piles of dust, you filch the priceless heirlooms and replace them with your cheap-but-realistic costume pieces. After the dust clears, you lead them the rest of the way to the main display room without any further incident.

The big day goes splendidly, with large crowds of wealthy visitors and some representatives from the House Gol family. You ensure that you are seen at every opportunity, with constant witnesses to your moves. That night, as you predicted, several thieves attempt their own robberies, but none succeed as well as you. Most are handily apprehended by the watchmen. You allow a single thief to make it as far as the inner display area before arresting her; should your own theft ever be detected, you might be able to pin it on her.

The gems are hot property, but you find a fence who will pay for them with no questions asked. Few will ever know that you did this crime, but you have proven yourself as one of the most talented thieves in all of Skal.
fields.title: Chief Thief

fields.description:
"Oh, how nice to see you, #TITLE_NAME#! I do appreciate what you did, making this cottage available for me."

You describe your wish to further investigate the depths of the ether. She seems delighted by your initiative, but warns you, "I'm afraid you've already exceeded the practical limits of my abilities. I'm primarily a scholar: I can do a few tricks here and there, but most of what I know comes purely from books."

She seems to sense some disappointment from you. "That doesn't mean I can't be of help, though! In fact, I know exactly the person you should speak with about this. Visit my old mentor Yanofol in the Tandan countryside. He's… well, to be honest, he's completely insane. However, he's also one of the most talented practical etherists I've met. If you can survive your time with him, you'll learn more than most of us manage in an entire lifetime!"
fields.title: Private Tutor

fields.description: "No, no, no, no, no, no, no, NO!" screams Yanofol. "Not like that! Push me pull you! You can't do anything right!" How abusive. He does seem to be on to something, though… you WERE attempting to pull at the fruit, which only hastened its approach to your body. Another tack must be necessary.
fields.title: Plucked

fields.description:
"Fri yi yi yi! Oh, joyous #MAN_WOMAN#! There be hope for you yet! Here, have a tasty coin!"

What just happened, exactly? You saw the apple rushing towards you… you felt its movement through the ether… then, you reached out, and instead of grabbing it, your ether force slapped it away. It's a very different sensation than pulling. Really an opposite, in fact. You'll need to study it more. Hopefully in a manner that doesn't involve more fruit juices splattering over your face.
fields.title: Bounce

fields.description: Try as you might, you can't seem to affect the fenceposts through the ether. You push waves out through ether, but they seem to simply break when they reach the fence's edge, parting like water flowing around a rock in a stream. Yanofol doesn't even speak, simply sticking his tongue out in disappointment.
fields.title: Creaking

fields.description: You focus on the ether as you work to push down the fence. When pulling through ether, it felt as if you were pulling on a rope to drag an object towards you. One can't push a rope, though, so a new approach is required. It's more like you're constantly lobbing small rocks at the item, with each hit pushing it infinitesimally farther back. You gradually increase the speed until you can no longer distinguish between each individual blow. Finally, with a loud "crack!", the fence splits apart and falls into the neighbor's yard. Yanofol can't contain his glee. "That's it! That's it! Look at what I did, there! Me, all me! Come, let's celebrate with fruited wine and burnt toast!"
fields.title: Counterstrike

fields.description: You pick a small rock that seems like it should be easy to move, but the cat wanders near it, breaking your concentration. It stalks insolently away before you can do anything the least bit scary to it. Yanofol beats you about the head while claiming you are plotting with the cat against him.
fields.title: Motionless

fields.description: You buffet a rock with several short, stern waves through the ether. The cat freezes and gazes intently at it. You increase the force projected. The rock begins to roll towards it. The cat hisses, spits, extends its claws, turns around, and leaps into the neighbor's yard, leaving loud shouts of anger in its wake. Yanofol laughs unceasingly. "Two for one! They deserve each other! Good show, good show. We should charge for admission." Nobody else is here.
fields.title: Raised Fur

fields.description: Yanofol seems to have anticipated your move. When you reach out to push over his bucket, you sense a force emanating back out from him, holding it upright. He grins at you in utter delight. Then slowly, deliberately, he transports the bucket above your head, turns it upside-down, and giggles softly while turnip after turnip falls down and splats against your head.
fields.title: Batted Back

fields.description: You lash out through the ether, knocking over the bucket and spilling its contents to the floor, so quickly that Yanofol doesn't have time to react. He pretends that nothing happened, and continues eating from his bowl. His invective against the ceiling seems to have intensified, though. Later in the day you see the soiled turnips dressed up in pretty ribbons and placed in your backpack.
fields.title: Overturned

fields.description: Oh dear. Yanofol's dishes are terribly fragile. And expensive-looking. He doesn't seem overly disturbed by the hundreds of royals' worth of fine dining equipment that you're clumsily destroying, though. His neighbors look on in horrified astonishment as the debacle continues to escalate, then mutter excuses and race for the door before the dessert course arrives. Yanofol claps you on the back. "Good show, #NAME#. Let's try it again tomorrow, hmmmmmm?"
fields.title: Crash! Tinkle! Shatter!

fields.description: The table is exactingly set. At the end of each course, you grandly slide the dishes off the table from the far end of the room, collecting them in the sink for later washing. Fresh courses are shoved out from the kitchen, hovering in the air in front of the astonished neighbors' eyes, while Yanofol weaves his own ether to ladle out the contents onto each dish. The evening passes in a pleasant but bewildering rush, and the neighbors eventually exit in a daze without ever broaching any of their complaints to the host. Yanofol yawns, eats the remaining beef, climbs onto the table and falls asleep. Leaving you to do all the dishes! Hmph.
fields.title: Ethereal Elegance

fields.description: As silly as he seems, Yanofol is extraordinarily powerful at wielding ether. He even lets you project the first blows, but swats them aside with his own emanations, and then proceeds to force you steadily back, back, off the rock and into the water. The onlookers holler and jeer, paying off the bets, but Yanofol graciously extends a hand to you. "Nevermind these yapping wagons," he confides conspiratorially. "Ludicrous bellyachers, the lot of them. Wouldn't know a flamanig from a peterpot! Now: hand over your money and nobody gets hurt."
fields.title: Ker-splash

fields.description: Yanofol's face is twisted into a crazed rictus of delight. He seems convinced he has you. He doesn't even try to strike first, but stands there contentedly when the duel begins. His eyes open wide when your powerful push hits him in the chest and he begins to slide backwards. Shrieking and cursing, he begins to mount his own counter-attack, but it's too late: your ethereal pushing has gained momentum, carrying him back, down, and into the water. Gasps of astonishment and a few cheers arise from the onlookers on shore. It seems like you were the long-shot, and you have made a few people a lot of money. The bookkeeper hands you a share of the winnings while Yanofol sputters at you while sitting in the waist-deep water: "Ingrate! Fool! I gave you everything, and this is how you repay me! I knew you were in league with the etherists! With the climbing ivy and the soaring seagulls and last week's rainstorm! Well, this is it. We're through! I'll never teach you anything ever again ever!" It looks like this is the end of your apprenticeship with Yanofol. Fortunately, by besting him at his own test, you've probably already learned most of what he had to teach you anyways. Your knowledge of ether and power over it continues to grow; where will it take you next?
fields.title: Remastered

fields.description:
The etherist greets you warmly. When you mention your interest in furthering your studies, she exclaims, "But of course! Studying ether happens to be a specialty of mine. If you wish to reach the pinnacle of our profession, there's really only one place to be: the lyceum in the Kingdom."

She frowns briefly. "Of course, they won't take just anyone. There are more etherists in Lok than room in their school, and they prefer to admit those who have shown initiative in learning, and generosity in sharing their findings with others. Someone who has written a treatise that extends our understanding of how ether works would almost certainly be admitted to the lyceum."

What sort of topic would attract their attention? The etherist has an idea: "Some colleagues of mine have been looking into the question of how ether interacts with the visible, natural world. They have found it a fruitful area of study. You might start by examining various types of natural phenomena, and seeing if and how ether can affect them."
fields.title: Research Project

fields.description: There's no wind to be had. You pull around ether for a while, but it never develops into anything substantial like a real, solid breeze. Discouraging.
fields.title: Becalmed

fields.description:
You find a nice, solid breeze going, and pay close attention to it. You can add a flow of ether to it to increase the breeze's strength, but it feels… different, somehow. The breeze seems to be traveling through the ether, and its strength and course can be altered when you tweak the ether in or around it; but it's surprisingly difficult to start a breeze from scratch, and you really doubt that an etherist is behind every breeze in the land. 

Most likely, the wind starts as the result of some natural act, and then proceeds through ether. Which, of course, is natural as well. Intriguing. You write down your latest observations and publish a small monograph on the topic.
fields.title: Breezing By

fields.description: You can see that your ether manipulation is causing water to swirl and eddy below the surface, but you can't feel what's happening down there. More work will be required.
fields.title: Murky

fields.description:
Ether definitely extends below water; it's harder to feel what items your ether flows are touching, but as long as you can maintain a clear line of sight, you can work almost as effectively down there as on land. You experiment with starting some currents that eventually turn into waves. It feels much more exhausting than starting a breeze. As far as you can tell, the water is "heavier" than air, and thus requires a greater force of ether to move.

You capture the findings from your latest experiments and write them down. Some people will be quite interested to read this.
fields.title: Different Flow

fields.description: You find a herd of deer, but as soon as you reach out through the ether, they immediately scatter. That seems to indicate that they can sense the presence of ether, even when you aren't directly targeting the creature, but otherwise doesn't teach you much.
fields.title: Fled

fields.description:
A herd of sheep stares at you curiously when you start touching the ether nearby. So, they can sense it, even though most people probably would not notice ether unless you directly touched them. When you reach out farther and send a loop around a nearby lamb, it stiffens, and then relaxes. You can gently move the animal around like you would an inanimate object, though it complains when you do so. Rather ineffectually: it seems like animals, or at least these lambs, are unable to manipulate ether themselves, and so can't effectively resist your actions.

Your readers will be interested to learn about your latest observations. You make note of the time and surroundings while writing up an update to your monograph.
fields.title: Aware

fields.description: Perhaps you're just tired today, but you can't seem to make any headway on your experiments, failing to even get inside materials you know you've entered before.
fields.title: Thwarted

fields.description:
With enough effort, you can reach out through ether and draw ether through any material. Different types of items seem to require radically different amounts of effort, though. Porous items like dry wood and unglazed pottery can be penetrated fairly easy. Metallic items, though, need extreme force and concentration, and even then you can only draw a very narrow thread of ether through. The thickness of an item also affects its permeability, though not as severely as the type of the material does.

Your growing body of readers will be very interested to read your thoughts on the topic.
fields.title: Exploring

fields.description: The storm is powerful, but no lightning presents itself. Your own attempts to add lightning to the turmoil prove fruitless.
fields.title: All Wet

fields.description:
The large, ominous storm sweeps through the area, drenching every surface. You tentatively reach out through the ether and sense the turmoil in the clouds. 

Lightning leaps from the sky to the ground. It moves through the ether, traveling much faster than a physical object could; it's as if a thread made of ether turned solid and deadly in an instant. You still can't quite sense exactly what caused the lightning to begin in the first place, though it does not appear to be anything within ether. The ether merely transmits the lightning, it does not cause it.

You are probably the first #MAN_WOMAN# to study lightning in the context of ether. Your readers will be interested in your findings.
fields.title: Shocking

fields.description:
You find a place far from habitation to minimize harm to bodies and property. Sitting on a rock, you focus on the ground beneath you, gradually expanding your projections of ether through the porous rock. You go down, down, down, deep within the earth. Finally, you discover a small gap or fault where the earth rubs against itself. You take a deep breath and begin to work, vibrating the ether back and forth.

As you had hoped and feared, the spark of your machinations is picked up by the surrounding ether. Encased in rock, the ether transmits your emanations, and a low rumble begins. You then break off your involvement; now that it has started, it can carry on its own. Sure enough, the rumble builds, turning into a small but impressive earthquake that throws you to the ground and shakes fruit loose from nearby trees.

A great success! You collect your earlier writings together and add the account of your capstone experiment, publishing the entire work under the title "Ethereal Energy: A Medium for Nature." Copies sell briskly. After a week you receive a missive from the lyceum in the Kingdom, inviting you to visit and discuss your findings in person with other scholars.
fields.title: Move It
